This conclusion of mine was virtually confirmed when the four and a half hours of trial was shown again on national TV in 1988 .

 The 1988 Tribune Entertainment special was a phenomenal 221,516 . The special was broadcast on Sunday, July 28, 1988 . It was the first time the show had aired on PBS .
 Eighty percent voted guilty, 20 percent not guilty, and 71 percent of the television audience said that Oswald was part of a conspiracy . After the audience watched only four and a half hours of the trial, the number dropped to 71 percent .

 There can be no question that the FBI spent thousands of man-hours investigating matters that had nothing to do with Oswald killing Kennedy . The FBI spent the majority of the time looking into whether Oswald was involved with anyone else in the assassination .

 The rifle was originally designed in 1891 as a 6.5-millimeter weapon . It was produced in new models from 1891, 1938, and 1941 . New models were produced in three different models .
 After the outbreak of World War II, the Italian government continued to produce many 6.5-millimeter versions in order to use up large stocks of ammunition on hand . The Italian government produced many versions of the weapon in WWII .
 The 6.5-millimeter Carcanos are designated as model 91/38, to distinguish them from model 38, the designation for a 7.35 millimeter rifle . The 6/38 model is the same name as model 38 for model 38 .

 President William Henry Harrison died in office of pneumonia exactly one month after being sworn in . John Tyler, his vice president, arrogated to himself the title as well as the powers and duties of the president . This practice, which has no constitutional basis, all started in 1841 .
 In any event, all illegitimacy and ambiguity was removed by the ratification of the Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution on February 10,1967 .

With a different presidential administration, history almost assuredly would have been different

 The difficulty of finding the bullet that entered Kennedy’s upper back is reminiscent of the much longer search for a bullet to the back of President James A Garfield, shot by Charles Guiteau on July 2,1881 .
 Doctors probed for the bullet that entered Garfield’s right back with unsterilized instruments or their bare hands, a common practice at the time . Garfield lingered near death for eighty days after the bullet entered his right back .
 Guiteau severely criticized Garfield’s doctors, claiming that it was they, not he, who killed Garfield . He also claimed that Garfield's doctors were responsible for the death of Garfield .
 The bullet was finally found during the autopsy following Garfield’s death on September 19, 1881 . Garfield died in 1881 from complications complications .
 The location of the bullet in Garfield's body became a national obsession . Many people offered advice on how to locate it .
 One citizen wrote to the White House that the doctors should simply turn the president upside-down and see if the bullet would fall out . The White House responded to the request .

 After Secret Service took custody of Marina, Ruth lost track of her for several weeks . Mail coming to her house for Marina from around the country was sent by Ruth to the Irving police for forwarding .
 Since the assassination weekend, other than one phone call from Marina to Ruth expressing her gratitude to Ruth for everything, Marina was making herself very scarce . The assassination weekend was the last weekend .

 The FBI divided its investigation of the assassination between two main divisions . The Domestic Intelligence Division was responsible for the investigation of Oswald’s activities, associations, and motivations, including the question of conspiracy .

 The Warren Commission concluded that the FBI had more than enough information in its possession to list Oswald as a potential threat to the safety of the president . Oswald's pro-Castro activities, his contact with the Soviet embassy in Mexico led to the Secret Service, the commission said .
 Commission did not go on to say that if the FBI had done this, the assassination would not have occurred . It was a serious indictment by the Commission of the FBI’s pre-assassination investigation of Oswald .

 The Warren Commission arranged top-secret security clearance for every member of its staff . Some information in the hands of the security agencies was kept from the Warren Commission on the grounds that it was classified .
 The committee made its own determination on each clearance . After consultation with the two agencies, the committee made the decision .
 Committee members signed memoranda of understanding with each of the agencies to establish procedures on how sensitive documents were to be handled . At the same time, committee made sure that its own procedures for handling classified documents respected the integrity of the security system .
 The committee wanted to ensure that its members and staff would have access to all classified information completely unsanitized . No “sources or methods” information was removed from the material, committee says .

 The National Archives had a rule, which applied across the board to all historical records that federal agencies and commissions turned over to them, that the records would not be released to the public for seventy-five years .
 NARA began its existence as an independent federal agency called the National Archives Establishment in 1934 under President Franklin D Roosevelt .
 It was incorporated into the General Services Administration, answerable to the administrator of the GSA, in 1949 . The GSA is now a part of the General Service Administration .
 In 1984, it was separated from the GSA and currently is once again an independent federal agency . The agency is an executive branch of the United States government .

 At that time, it decided that it was in the best interests of all concerned that the policy relating to the Commission’s records provide for the fullest possible disclosure .
 The Commission, after full consideration, concluded that it did not have either the authority or the necessary information to determine the technical questions as to when the classified materials should be released without injury to the security of the country .
 It decided that the responsibility for that decision must of necessity be left with the originating agencies and the Attorney General, as the chief legal officer, in accordance with established law and policies .
 The Commission assumed that all of the determinations by the agencies and the Attorney General would be made in recognition of the overriding consideration of the fullest possible disclosure .
 We hope that this report of the attitude and conclusions of the Commission concerning the full disclosure of its records will be helpful to you in the formulation of your proposal for making the materials of the . Commission now in the National Archives available to the public .

 The JFK Act and ARRB were almost, by definition, an exercise in futility . Therefore, if the purpose of the JFK Act was to find out if such documentary evidence existed among the previously unreleased Warren Commission and HSCA records, it would be futile .
 JFK Act and ARRB have become an important part of the historical record of the assassination . However, despite this inherent futility, inasmuch as this is called for, a brief discussion of them is needed .
 The Warren Commission and HSCA records have been released to the public . However, the situation perhaps isn’t quite as black and white as I have painted it here . The whole debate has been raging for decades over the wisdom of releasing them .
 Though a smokinggun incriminating document would never be found in the archives, it is undeniably true that whenever anyone attempts to destroy much incriminating material, here and there hints of conspiracy and complicity somehow continue to survive .
 A surviving document, by itself, would appear to be benign, and hence wasn’t destroyed . But in the hands of a good researcher this document may contain information that, in conjunction with other information or documents, becomes a part of the mosaic pointing toward wrongdoing .
 If there was a conspiracy to murder Kennedy, the diligent search for documents that are part of the assassination record is not, per se, an automatically fruitless undertaking . So if there was there was an assassination record, an examination of documents is possible .
 This fight over secrecy reached its zenith in America during the paranoia of the cold war . It continued, almost unabated, until the collapse of the Soviet Union helped shift, at least somewhat, the free world’s emphasis .
 Prior to 1946 in America, there was no federal statute entitling any citizen to secure the records of any federal agency . Short of a subpoena in an ongoing lawsuit, short of subpoena, a subpoena was required in the case .
 Congress passed a law in 2010 requiring every federal agency to publish final opinions or orders resulting from administrative proceedings . The law requires that every agency publish or “make available to public inspection” of its final opinions .
 Freedom of Information Act of 1966 went into effect on July 4, 1967 . First major breakthrough and crack in the federal secrecy armor came in the landmark act of 1966 . Department of Justice guidelines were never codified into statutory law .
 Most FOIA requests do not deal with the Kennedy assassination, indicating Americans' appetite for government information of all kinds . It should be noted that most FOIA requests don't deal with Kennedy assassination .
 In 1990, federal agencies received 491,000 FOIA requests and spent $83 million responding to them . For instance, in 1990, the federal government responded to more than 500,000 requests .
 The Defense Department received 118,000 requests; the Justice Department, 62,000; the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 45,000 . The Environmental Protection Agency, 39,000, the FBI, 11,000 and the CIA, 4,000. The Justice Department received 62,

 There are several reasons for this, he said, proceeding to mention a few . "There is several reasons" for this," he said .
 In many cases, they don't know for certain whether information in a document is harmful, but they consider there’s always a possibility it might be in some way they don’t even know about .
 They view requesters as subversives, a class of people who are looking for information to hurt them . The government says requesters are people who want to hurt the government .

 Previous assassination-related commissions and committees were established for the purpose of drawing conclusions about the assassination . Previous commission and committees have been established to examine the assassination of JFK .
 Under the JFK Act, all congressional records on the assassination, including, most importantly, the records of the HSCA that had not been published in its twelve volumes were now subject to release to the public .
 Under FOIA, under FOIA, nondisclosure could be permanent under many situations . But under Section 6 of the JFK Act, only a "postponement" was possible .
 JFK Act limits "postponements" under JFK Act . JFK Act has a virtual limit under the law . The act was passed by Congress last year .
 The JFK Act allowed only the ARRB, not private citizens, to procure assassination records under it . The courts have held that throughout the period of the Act, private citizens and the general public still had to continue to seek assassination records .
 Assassination Archives and Research Center sought some FBI records under FOIA relating to assassination figure Marita Lorenz . In 1993, the FBI denied some FOIA requests relating to Lorenz, which the center sought under FOIA . The FBI denied the request .
 Most of the same litany of grounds (in addition to national security) for nondisclosure exists under the JFK Act as under FOIA . Even if the source or method of operation were not currently being utilized, an exemption could still be sustained .
 The “current” requirement was an obvious compromise between the public’s right to know and the traditional concern of law enforcement and intelligence agencies like the FBI and the CIA to protect, above all else, their sources and methods of operation .
 The Review Board says that definition is too restrictive and won't satisfy the conspiracy community . The Board says it would not satisfy the community, which had a reputation for seizing on a far-out tidbit of information .
 The Review Board expanded the definition of an assassination record to include all records . The JFK Act also compelled the release of assassination records of “any State or local law enforcement office that provided support or assistance”
 The Dallas Police Department released all of its documents on the case for inspection by the public in 1992 . Months before the JFK Act was even enacted, the Dallas City Council voted to release the case files .
 The ARRB, with broad powers, began to implement the JFK Act on April 11,1994 . It includes the power to subpoena witnesses and documents and grant witnesses immunity from prosecution .
 JFK Act went into effect October 26, 1992, and it set forth its objective of releasing JFK assassination-related documents to the public . By April of 1994, federal agencies had voluntarily declassified thousands of documents .
 The Review Board was dealing with about sixty-two-thousand assassination-related documents . The documents were being opposed by one of the twenty-three agencies or entities that possessed them .
 Of these, 33,176 were eventually released by the agencies without a ruling by the Review Board . Of those released, only 33,000 were released by agencies . The Review Board has yet to rule on the issue .
 The Review Board would not grant postponements for certain types of information, so they voluntarily withdrew their request for postponement before the ARRB ruled on them . This was so because once the Review Board started to establish its voting patterns, agencies or entities began to .
 Only 29,420 documents were reviewed by the Review Board . 49 percent of those documents were CIA documents . 34 percent were FBI documents .
 Judge Tunheim told me that these approximately twenty-nine thousand documents contained redacted material . Most of them had not been released by the agencies involved in the investigation, he said .
 The materials were legally transferred by the Kennedy family to the archives on October 29, 1966 . The materials are now housed in the archives .

 Conspiracy theorists have spent considerable money and time to get one or more assassination documents released from the archives . Without exception, when successful, they found there was nothing of any value in them .
 They found that their assumption that the government’s fighting so tenaciously with them to withhold the document meant it was hiding something of relevance to the assassination was a non sequitur, they said .
 A federal agency was only withholding the identity of an intelligence source or methods of operation . Over and over they found, to their consternation, that a federal agency had only withheld the identity .
 In those cases where it wasn't, it was just plain bureaucratic obstinacy . In some cases, it wasn’t, it’s just plain bureaucracy .
 The ARRB released the same document unredacted, they learned the redacted material was of no evidentiary value to them . Later, the ARRB learned that the material was not of any apparentiary value .
 Nothing was found to contravene the findings of the Warren Commission and support their various theories of conspiracy . The conspiracy community were disappointed when nothing was found .
 Either the title or description of a document was provocative and the document itself itself was banal, or upon close inspection, a seemingly significant line of inquiry turned out to mean something completely different than initially thought .
 The ARRB got everything from the Secret Service it asked for, including a document containing the names of all known people who had threatened Kennedy within six months of the assassination . Eventually the ARRB was able to get the document .
 The Secret Service said that since many of these people had been institutionalized, to release their names, even though many are now dead, would compromise the Secret Service’s relationship with mental health providers for the mentally ill . Many of the names of the dead people are now deceased .
 The Secret Service appealed the Review Board's demand for the document to the president . President Clinton denied the Secret Service’s appeal before his term expired in 2001 . Under the JFK Act, the only person or entity an agency can appeal to is the president, not the courts .
 The other agency that wasn’t completely cooperative was President Clinton’s Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, a White House agency . The board was a bipartisan panel of intelligence experts .
 It appealed to the president the ARRB’s demand for minutes of the board during meetings in 1962-1963 regarding Cuba and Russia .
 Just before his second term expired in January of 2001, President Clinton also rejected the appeal of the Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board . President Clinton rejected the decision .
 The ARRB discontinued its operations on September 30,1998 . No future requests could be made under the Act .

 In 1962 the CIA’s Office of Biographic Registry compiled a five-volume set of profiles on Cuban leaders . When I asked for an example, he said he said that in 1962, the CIA had compiled five volumes of profiles .
 No smoking gun or even a smoldering ember of conspiracy was found . ARRB scoured the country for documents “reasonably related” to the assassination . The ARRB conducted an unprecedented four-year scavenger hunt .
 Dallas Police Department has two other official repositories of assassination documents . Documents relate to Parkland Hospital and custody of Jack Ruby following shooting of Oswald .
 In early 2006,1 asked John Slate, the city archivist at the Dallas Municipal Archives, to furnish me with the history of the JFK assassination records of the Dallas Police Department .
 I am grateful to Slate for writing me back on July 10, 2006, with the history I requested . I am also grateful for Slate for sending me back a copy of this article .
 The John F Kennedy/Dallas Police Department Collection contains 11,406 documents and photographs . It includes homicide reports, affidavits, witness statements, newspaper clippings and correspondence . The collection includes homicide and murder reports .
 The Dallas Municipal Archives possesses all of the original files except those that have been transferred permanently to the federal investigation collection held at the National Archives . The files are housed in the Dallas Municipal Archive .
 A first set of documents related to the Kennedy assassination were discovered by the city’s records management officer . The documents were discovered during a records inventory of the Dallas Police Department .
 The documents were housed between 1963 and 1989 in a filing cabinet with other historical materials . They were appraised as no longer administratively needed by police department .
 The documents were added in 1992, largely in response to the release of Oliver Stone’s film JFK, parts of which were shot in Dallas .
 In absence of meaningful local of federal open records laws until the 1970s, the Kennedy records were more forgotten than actually restricted . Few made specific written requests to the department or the police chief .
 Most citizens’ requests to the DPD for information were of a general nature . Most were directed to the Warren Commission volumes or to the National Archives .
 While it appeared the records were closed, in truth they were never meant to be restricted . The records were not closed, but they were meant to remain open .
 "We believe it can and should become public information. Unless we are specifically instructed otherwise from Washington, we believe it should be public information"
 Nearly thirty years later the chief’s forgotten utterance finally became reality . Nearly 30 years later, the chief's forgotten utterment finally becomes reality .
 The six series in the collection are organized according to the organizational functions of the police department . They are kept in the same order as they were physically stored at the department .
 During the processing of the collection a subject and name index was generated to create further access points . During the process of the . processing of . the . collection a . subject and . name index were generated to generate further access . points .
 In 1967 through 1969, photocopied newspaper and magazine articles relating to New Orleans district attorney Jim Garrison’s investigation were added to document that case . In 1969, the photos were used to document Garrison's investigation .
 In 2005, duplicate photographic prints and documents (concerning Oswald’s murder and the sending of his clothing to the National Archives) stolen from DPD at an undetermined time were discovered and seized during a 2004 drug raid . Oswald's clothing was sent to the Archives in 2005 .
 Several items of correspondence in the collection are requests for access written during the 1960s connected with the official federal investigation of the incident . The collection includes correspondence from the federal government .
 An early transfer of material to the FBI is documented in a December 3,1963, letter from Chief Curry to FBI field agent J Gordon Shanklin . Chief Curry transferred material to FBI in 1963 .
 The FBI microfilmed files on Lee Harvey Oswald’s murder upon receipt . The FBI returned a roll to DPD while the originals were sent to Washington . Curry confirmed that files on Oswald's murder were microfiled .
 Subsequent requests for information on various aspects of the larger investigation were made by the FBI or other federal agencies over a number of months . There is a reasonably consistent paper trail of what was sent to Washington .
 Lee Rankin, general counsel for the Warren Commission, requested the police department to provide everything they had relating to Lee Harvey Oswald to the Commission . The letter was sent in 1964 by Texas attorney general Waggoner Carr .
 Approximately 30% of DPD Kennedy records in the Dallas Municipal Archives are second-generation carbon copies or photocopies from originals . Many original items were never returned and retained permanently by the Warren Commission or FBI .
 Author William Manchester contacted Chief Curry in June 1964 as he was conducting research for Death of a President . Chief Curry was the subject of a book called Death of the President .
 A request to visit Curry was apparently made to review police records . The request was apparently a request to see Curry, but also review records .

 There is no further correspondence with Byrd, nor did Byrd appear at the hearings, as far as is known . Byrd died in 1968 .
 In 1976, David Martin, legal counsel to the U.S. Secret Service, received approval to release documents in possession of the federal agency to early Warren Commission critic and activist Mark Lane .
 A pioneering digitalization project funded by Wang Laboratories in 1992 created a virtual collection for use at a public computer terminal .  Improvements in digital scanning technology will necessitate the re-scanning of portions of the collection . The original project was a significant achievement .
 Researchers may continue to use the photocopy and microfilm sets by appointment . Researchers may also continue to collect microfilm samples from the library .

 Dallas County Commissioners Court ordered all county records pertaining to the Kennedy assassination be located and transferred to the Dallas County Historical Foundation . The foundation operates the Museum .
 At that time, the Museum received numerous original and photocopied Parkland Hospital records related to the assassination . The Museum received many original records from the hospital .
 The order also encouraged county elected officials to also round up Kennedy files . Kennedy files should be transferred to the Dallas County Historical Foundation, the order says .
 The files were brought to the attention of the Museum at that time and arrangements were made to receive them early the following year .

 The county had no assassination files in storage from either the sheriff or anyone else . The county's sheriff's office says the files are in storage, but the county has no files .

 Gary Mack, then program director for KFJZ-FM in Fort Worth, Texas, developed an interest in the assassination after seeing the Zapruder film on Geraldo Rivera’s ABC national television show the year before . Penn Jones Jr. met with conspiracy theorist Penn Jones
 Jones felt that the communications were jammed on purpose, and even though the open microphone was on channel 1, which was not being used for motorcade communications, he believed it was a motorcycle that was part of the motorcade .
 Jones suggested that perhaps the open microphone picked up the sound of the shots fired at the president and transmitted them back to Dallas police headquarters, where they were recorded on the tapes .
 Dallas Police Department had two radio channels to commumcare with policemen . Each of the radio channels was on a different frequency . The Dallas police department had two different radio channels .
 The cyclist, by clicking a switch, could go from one channel to another but could never be on two channels at the same time . The dispatcher, at police headquarters, had the ability to transmit simultaneously on both channels .
 To transmit, cyclist had to pick up the microphone, depress the transmitter button (“pushto-talk button”) on the microphone . Cyclist had to keep the button depressed while talking .
 McLain asked if it would be possible for the microphone button to be stuck in the open position . McLain said yes, and said it was possible for it to be possible .
 When the microphone button is not depressed, the police radio is in the “receiving” or “monitoring” position or mode in which the cyclist can hear transmissions from the police dispatcher . When the radio is not engaged, then the cyclist is able to hear
 Occasionally, the microphone button will stick when pressed down, leaving the radio in transmission mode even after the officer has finished speaking and released the button . The microphone button can stick in the microphone while the officer is talking .
 Once a motorcyclist depresses the microphone button to transmit, this does not preclude all other cyclists from talking to the police dispatcher at that time . Once a rider depresses a microphone button, all cyclists can talk to the dispatcher .
 If two or more cyclists are talking at the same time, you’d normally have almost incomprehensible voice-overs . They can still transmit on that channel, but can still be heard on the other channel .
 The term cross talk refers to a conversation being broadcast on one radio channel that is picked up by a nearby police microphone that is on a different radio channel . The conversation is retransmitted, by this other microphone, back to the dispatcher’s Dictabelt at police headquarters
 Made by Dallas radio reporter Sam Pate, it later appeared on the Colpix Inc. record album Four Days That Shocked the World .

 The Dallas police communications system was routinely recorded onto thin, plastic belts and disks by two separate duplex recording units . The Dallas communications system is routinely recorded on thin plastic belts, disks .
 Channel 1 was recorded on a Dictaphone A2TC, Model 5, belt recorder purchased by the department in 1957 . Channel 1 recorded on Channel 1 on a belt recorder .
 Channel 2 (the one for special-event radio traffic) was recorded on a Gray Corporation “Audograph” flat disk recorder that was bought in the early 1950s . Channel 2 was recorded using the Gray Corporation "Audograph" flat disk recorder .
 Both duplex devices consisted of one unit set to record and one set to standby mode . The second unit was set to take over as soon as the first unit contained a full recording . The duplex device was used to record a full version of the recording .

 At 12:31 (about 5 seconds after the decrease in the sound), he said he heard on the channel 1 tape “four groups” or “patterns” of “impulse sounds” that his BBN team thought might be gunshots . Also at
 Dallas police radio system had a “limiter’s built into it that takes an extra loud sound and reduces it down to an acceptable level for transmission through the radio . The limiter has made these sounds, if indeed they were gunshot sounds, “quiet.”
 It is so distorted that you don’t have the impression of hearing gunshot. So it’s so distorted you don't have to hear gunshot. The sound of the gunshot is distorted, so it is not the sound of a gunshot .
 The ability of an officer to transmit a message from his cycle when a microphone from another cycle is stuck in the open position was based on its proximity to a number of relay towers located throughout the city . The towers routed radio signals back to the central dispatch room via voice-grade telephone lines
 An officer whose radio was close enough to a relay tower might be able to override the signal from the stuck mike and transmit a message, though distorted . Others, in more distant locations, might only produce brief heterodyne tones .
 Others might not be able to transmit or produce any sounds at all . Still others might be unable to produce any sound .
 The closest relay tower to Dealey Plaza, less than a mile away, was atop the Adolphus hotel, a witness says . The closest tower was atop a Dallas Police Department radio dispatcher at the time .
 Bowles had worked in the dispatcher’s office for ten years and is probably the leading authority on the channel 1 tape . Bowles worked for the dispatcher's office for 10 years .
 Bowles prepared a rebuttal to the HSCA’s fourth-shot conclusion in 1979 . Bowles listened to the same magnetic copy of the original Dictabelt he had used in 1964 and put on earphones .
 "A series of randomly spaced, loud clicks and pops" can be heard, lasting around ten seconds . tHorsefeathers, says Bowles, last for around 10 seconds .
 Bowles told me in November of 2004 that several times before and after the assassination he personally has heard the sound of gunshots on channel 1 tapes . Bowles said several times .
 The microphone becomes unstuck, turning off, then back on again . The noises could be the result of motorcycle engine misfiring, or noises generated by the motorcycle’s ignition system .
 The impulse sounds could also be due to scratches on the surface of the Dictabelt . The impulse sound is also thought to be caused by scratches in the surface . The sound is similar to the sound waves of the iPod touch .

 Early on Sunday, August 20, 1978, a crowd began to gather in Dealey Plaza to witness the historic test firings . The tests began just after dawn, and began just before dawn .
 Part of tem had a limiter, but he said it only “cut off the extreme highs and lows” of a loud sound . The two hundred or so people who showed up were mostly members of the media .
 HSCA staff members, seven acoustic experts, photographic consultant, and thirty-three Dallas police officers assembled . The investigative team that had been assembled consisted of four staff members . Thirty-three police officers were also present .
 Acoustic experts from BBN decided that none of the changes would significantly alter the acoustic fingerprints of the test shots they planned to fire .
 Dallas police sharpshooter Jerry Compton was instructed to fire, from the sniper’s nest, a Mannlicher-Carcano rifle similar to the one found on the sixth floor in 1963 . Clint L Metcalf, the marksman stationed behind the stockade fence atop
 The type of weapon allegedly fired from the grassy knoll was unknown . Acoustic scientists wanted to make sure they had examples of test shots fired from both supersonic and subsonic weapons .
 Neither marksman used the telescopic sights of their weapons, preferring the safety of the iron sights, which allowed them to see the immediate area around the targets .
 Preliminary examination of tape shows ‘pops and clicks” at intervals that matched position of limousine at Zapruder frames 160, 200, and 313 . Three were based on preliminary examination of the tape .
 A fourth target was placed at the south curb of Main Street, near the Triple Underpass, where a bullet ricocheted . The 1963 investigation showed that the 1963 investigation was inconclusive . The investigation found that the fourth target had been placed at Main Street .
 The HSCA ultimately concluded that the Z200 shot was fired a few frames earlier than believed at the time of the test firing . The biggest problem for the acoustic team was finding a method of determining the origin of the shot .
 The BBN experts decided that the motorcycle had to have been somewhere within Dealey Plaza to pick up the sound of the gunfire . The experts say it had to be somewhere within the area to hear the gunshots .
 The motorcycle was likely to be no more than about 18 feet from the center of the 40-foot-wide street . BBN arranged three groups of twelve microphones each (for a total of thirty-six possible positions) spaced at 18-foot intervals .
 Test shots would be fired and recorded for each of the three separate groups of microphone positions . Test shots were fired to record each of three separate positions .
 In this way, scientists reasoned that in a worst-case scenario, motorcycle position would be no more than 18 feet from any test microphone location .
 The theory behind this rather complicated acoustic test was that a gunshot produces an initial impulse sound, followed by a series of echoes . The test was designed to test the sound of a gunshot fired .
 Each microphone position would record a sequence of uniquely spaced impulse sounds depending on the location of the shooter, the target, and echo-producing structures surrounding that microphone . The sound is unique to the position of each microphone position and the location .
 The committee could obtain unique “acoustical fingerprints” of various combinations of shooter, target, and microphone locations .
 If acoustical fingerprints produced in the 1978 reconstruction matched those on the 1963 police dispatch tape, it would be “a strong indication” that the impulse sounds on the police tape were gunshots recorded by an open microphone in the motorcade .
 Over the next seventeen days, BBN experts made 2,592 comparisons between the recorded test shots and the impulse sounds on the Dallas police tape . Over the course of the day, experts compared the test shots to the sounds recorded on the tape .
 Police were looking for a close match between the police tape impulses and the arrival of echoes at each microphone position as recorded during the test firings . What they were looking at was a . close match .
 The location of the motorcycle’s open microphone was unknown . It was sixty-eight degrees in Dallas on the day of the assassination, while the temperature hit nearly ninety degrees .
 The difference in temperature was figured into the final calculations by the acoustic experts . The temperature was also figured into calculations by acoustic experts.
 Each potential match also had to have a sufficiently high “correlation coefficient,” a number that describes the quality of the match between a test echo pattern and an impulse sound sequence on the tape .
 A correlation coefficient of 0. or higher (with 1. being perfect) was considered sufficient to catch all impulse sound sequences that might actually represent true gunfire . The correlation coefficient was 0.5 to 0.7% .
 The correlation coefficient was set to be high, but it also allowed the possibility that “random noise or other factors” would also read as a match . On the other hand, setting the correlation coefficient that high allowed .
 After comparing all 2,592 combinations of echo patterns recorded during the test firing with the ‘pops and clicks” on the eight-second sequence of the 1963 Dallas police tape, BBN acoustic team discovered fifteen test echo patterns that were within the .006-second window and
 Fifteen patterns were found to be grouped around four different periods of time on the Dallas police tape, an indication that four shots had been fired . The patterns were grouped around the time four shots were fired .
 The BBN team plotted the location of the microphone of each “match” against the time shown on the police tape . To determine which of the fifteen “matches” were valid gunshot sounds, if any, and which were false, the team plotted each of the
 BBN calculated the probability that this could have occurred at random as less than 1 percent . The probability of this happening at random is 1 percent, BBN said .
 A motorcycle with an open microphone moved through Dealey Plaza and that it did record gunfire . According to BBN, this fact, in and of itself, tended to confirm that there was a motorcycle with a microphone moving through Dealy Plaza .
 BBN scientists said that the expected number of false alarms in an analysis this size was 13, but, as indicated, only six had been found . Though nine correlations remained, with “no other acoustical evidence that would help to determine which of the remaining nine correlations are false
 BBN believed there was only a fifty-fifty chance that any of the nine remaining correlations were actual gunshots . BBN believes two of the correlations almost certainly were gunshots .
 Time span between onset of first impulse pattern and onset of fourth impulse pattern was 7. seconds . From the channel 1 tape, the time span between the onset of the first . impulse pattern . and the onset . of the fourth impulse patterns was 7 seconds .
 When corrected for the time span, the real time span was 8. seconds . The tape recorder was running about 5 percent too slowly, BBN said .
 Barger called to give the committee the news . Barger found evidence of four shots, one of which came from the grassy knoll . The final calculations were completed on September 6, 1978 .
 Blakey suggested he come to Washington the day before he was scheduled to testify to discuss his work . Blakey: "I'm going to testify before a panel of experts will be able to discuss my work"
 Barger met with Blakey, Congressman Floyd J Fithian of Indiana, and Deputy Chief Counsel Gary Cornwell . Barger explained his methodology to explain his methodology .
 The men examined photographs taken at the time of the assassination to see if they could identify the motorcycle with the stuck microphone button . None of the photographs covered the time and place where they expected the motorcycle to be, Blakey said .
 For grassy knoll advocates, such as Blakey, Barger’s testimony was a disaster . For the HSCA, grassy-kills advocates, the testimony is a disaster, Blakey says .
 Blakey later understated the disaster when he wrote, “Barger turned out to be not very persuasive.”
 All the virtues that had made him a fine scientist worked against him as a witness . All of the virtues he had made himself a scientist, he said .
 Barger said he was only confident that two of the four impulse sounds were actual gunfire, not false alarms . Barger was poor at explaining himself, Blakey said . Everyone who understands the English language easily understood his testimony .
 The Warren Commission presented a massive amount of testimony that three shots were fired over the same period of time that Barger and his people analyzed, hearing two of those shots meant nothing . Barger's people say hearing two shots from the time of the time was meaningless .
 There is only a probability of “somewhere between 60 or 70 percent” that three shots were fired, Barger said . Barger went on to say that there was only a . probability of the three shots fired .
 Barger capped his damaging testimony by saying his findings were only a “potential corroborating force” for a finding of four shots . He added that they were also a ‘potential discrediting force’ to such a theory .
 HSCA staff huddled to work out a strategy in the hope of reducing the uncertainty of Barger’s analysis . Barger testified before the House of Representatives on Tuesday night .
 They didn't want to leave the question of a conspiracy in the Kennedy assassination to the flip of a coin . They didn’t want to . leave the . question of . a conspiracy to the . assassination to be left open to speculation .
 If they could only refine BBN’s work and come up with better percentages, they might help eliminate some of the doubt .
 Mark Weiss and Ernest Aschkenasy failed to find a way to take the data further . The BBC asked them to take a further look at the data, but they were initially optimistic .
 Barger, Weiss and Aschkenasy came up with a mathematical extension of BBN’s approach . They thought it could reduce the element of chance in their findings .
 Barger was unable to say that the grassy knoll shot actually existed with any certainty greater than fifty-fifty was because the position of the alleged motorcycle with the open microphone was unknown at the time of the test firings .
 Barger’s team was forced to place test microphones at 18-foot intervals along the motorcade route and fire from only one of many possible locations behind the stockade fence atop the grassy knoll .
 Barger used a .006-second coincidence window that allowed for the possibility that the open microphone was at least near, if not exactly at, one of the test microphone positions .
 The probability of deducing an actual gunshot was limited to 50 percent . The downside of using such a large window was that it increased the possibility of including false alarms in the test results .
 Weiss and Aschkenasy assumed they could increase the level of confidence in the result by finding a way to reduce the coincidence window to .001 of a second or less .
 BBN’s tests had already narrowed the likely location of the motorcycle with the open microphone at the time of the third shot to a small area at the beginning of Elm Street . Theoretically, they reasoned, this was possible because of the fact that the motorcycle was in the
 One way to rework the study would be to go back to Dealey Plaza and place test microphones 1 foot apart and fire from various locations atop the grassy knoll .
 This approach, however, could not be implemented because of the limited time and funds available to the committee . This approach would have been implemented, but it was not implemented .
 Weiss and Aschkenasy figured that the only practical way to acquire the necessary test echo patterns was to predict them analytically . Weiss: "Only practical way" to acquire necessary test patterns is to predict their patterns .
 Weiss and Aschkenasy located one sequence of impulse sounds on the Dallas tape that was “very similar” to the sequence of predicted echoes . Weiss: “Very similar’s sequence of echo sounds on Dallas tape is ‘similar’ to that predicted echoes
 A visual inspection showed that “almost all” of the impulse sounds and predicted echoes fell within the .001-second coincidence window they had established . “Almost all’s of the impulses sounds and predictions fell within .001 seconds,” they said .
 The impulse sounds on the police tape, identified as coming from the grassy knoll, were something other than gunshots . Weiss and Aschkenasy noted that the “high degree of correlation” between the sounds and the echo predictions did not preclude the possibility that the impulse sounds
 The probability that the impulse sounds on the tape would match the echo pattern predictions (within .001 of a second) and not be gunshots was very small, less than 5 percent . However, the probability of the sounds matching the pattern is very small .
 The path of the microphone, as it received the muzzle blast and its echoes, extends for about 6 feet along Elm Street . It received a muzzle blast, and its echo echoes, along the street .
 The uncertainty in the initial position is plus or minus 1 foot, which corresponds to the accuracy of measurements made on the topographical survey map” . tone wonders how Barger could feel that Weiss and Aschkenasy had validated his work .
 Weiss and Aschkenasy disagreed with every other impulse sound that Barger had identified as a gunshot . Weiss agreed that the head shot was fired at frame 312, but disagreed with the other impulse sounds . Barger was shot in the head .
 Barger and Weiss had to know that they were on the cusp of becoming important historical figures, and there was an intoxicating buzz, not only among them but also among Blakey and his closest associates . Barger, and particularly Weiss and Aschkenasy, had .
 Weiss and Aschkenasy, along with Barger, met with committee members in executive session . Weiss and Barger presented their united position on December 11, 1978 . Barger was elected to the House of Representatives .
 Many of the committee members were surprised by the finding . Although some had seen it coming, many had been surprised by it .
 They took turns quizzing experts, struggling to come to terms with what it meant if the experts were right .

 In a telephone interview and a letter to me, Bowles elaborated on the Doppler effect . Bowles: "Doppler Effect" is the result of a Doppling effect on the sound waves .
 It’s more than just a sound rising and then receding in intensity, which anyone could hear and which would not justify attributing the name of an individual to it . Anyone could hear the sound rising, receding and receding, anyone could .
 It refers to the “instant” when the change in sound occurs, Bowles says . Bowles: The sound is a "instant" when the sound of the sound occurs .
 At 12:33:01, channel 1 recorded the starting of low siren sounds, says Bowles .

 In recent years right through through the present, he has worked four days a week as a security officer at a large Cadillac dealership in Dallas .
 He and his wife have been living in the same Dallas home for forty-seven years . They also have had the same telephone number for close to half a century .

 FBI investigators match sound of a gunshot fired in Greensboro, North Carolina, in 1979 with the impulse sounds on the 1963 Dallas police tapes thought to be a shot fired from the grassy knoll . FBI investigators found that using the same correlation method, they could match the recorded sound of
 FBI report points out that it's impossible to determine how Weiss and Aschkenasy arrived at the conclusion that the impulse sounds were the result of a gunshot blast and not some other sound . The FBI report pointed out that the FBI report was impossible .
 The FBI noted that scientific literature shows that all sounds produce echoes off hard surfaces . This is one of the ways the HSCA acoustic team said they had determined these were gunshots .
 Detecting a shock wave (the other way Weiss and Aschkenasy attempted to distinguish sounds) accurately is very difficult, even under highquality forensic conditions . The shock wave itself produces a set of delay echoes which combine and change many characteristics of the muzzle blast sound .
 The FBI's Technical Services Division concluded that the HSCA’s three acoustic experts were almost a joke . In sum, the FBI said that the findings of the experts were 'almost a joke' The FBI said the findings were based on the three experts' findings .

 The CBA turned to the FBI to produce sound spectrograms of the Decker transmissions as heard over channels 1 and 2 of the Dallas police radio . The FBI’s Technical Services Division had investigators there use their exceptional sound analysis equipment .
 The HSCA found that Decker’s “hold everything secure” transmission on channel 2 was indeed picked up as cross talk on channel 1 . They found twenty-seven points of correlation over the course of the three-and-a-half-second transmission . The
 A spectrogram is a photograph of sound frequencies that plots the elapsed time of sounds along the horizontal axis, the frequency along the vertical axis, and the intensity of the frequency in shades of gray, with the darkest shades representing the loudest portions of the sound .
 Barger’s report to the HSCA erroneously said that Dallas police radio dispatchers for channels 1 and 2 used two different clocks that were synchronized with each other at the beginning of each month . Barger said that two different clock clocks were synchronized at the start of
 Police tapes “read out” the time “in full minutes only,” though estimates of the seconds into each minute could be made from the transmissions after each minute . Police tapes read out the time only in full minutes, but estimates of each minute can be made .
 FBI study: By the end of each month clocks could differ by as much as one minute . FBI study concluded that by the end each month the clocks could be different by up to a minute .

 The channel 2 recorder operated intermittently and was supposed to stop after 4 seconds of silence . The channel 1 recorder ran continuously through the period in question . It ran intermittently throughout the time .

 This is consistent with sirens heard at a stationary point if the presidential motorcade had passed close by . The motorcade is believed to have passed close to the White House .
 Simple common sense tells us that the open mike was not, as the HSCA concluded, in Dealey Plaza at the time of the assassination . Barger and his associates used mathematical calculations to make the decision .
 The CBA report said the omission of a “number of essential tests to confirm” their findings . This resulted, the report said, in the absence of “essential tests,” they said .
 Weiss and Aschkenasy omitted a basic test so basic that even I, a nonscientist, recognized that it had to be done . Even even I recognized that even he had to do the test .
 Scientists always try to test their hypotheses against known realities . Scientists try to find out if their hypothesis is true .
 This is so fundamental that it is even done in such scientifically superficial disciplines as polygraphy . This is even a scientifically superficial discipline like polygraphs, says Dr. Andrew Hammond .
 A polygraphy expert says polygraphers always ask ‘control questions’ that are unrelated to the matter the subject is being questioned about, but which the subject will almost assuredly lie about . Polygraphy experts say polygraphs always ask "control questions"
 In fact, sometimes the polygrapher will even tell the subject, when asking his name, to give a false name .
 The physiological response to the control question is then used as a basis for comparison with answers the subject gives to questions germane to the matter under investigation . The physiological responses are then used to compare with answers given to questions relevant to the investigation .
 The results of such an analysis,” the CBA said, could “not be considered reliable” unless the method had been “adequately tested on some other cases” CBA says . The results could not be “considered reliable’s�
 The CBA scientists released their final report on May 14, 1982, on the HSCA’s acoustic work . Proponents of the acoustic work were quick to react to the news .

 Mack charged in his newly founded conspiracy newsletter, Coverups!, that one of the flaws in the CBA’s debunking of the HSCA acoustic evidence was the detection of “automatic gain control” within the Decker cross talk transmission . Mack: The CBA detected
 Automatic gain control is a name given to specialized circuitry built into most radio equipment since the 1940s . It allows a radio signal to automatically adjust the loud and soft sounds being received into a constant, consistent level .
 Mack says engineers familiar with the 1963 Motorola Sensicon radio system used by the Dallas police “emphatically denied’t that AGC was present in the circuitry’s circuitry, therefore, could not have produced the effect detected by the committee . Mack countered the CBA
 The presence of AGC indicated that the Dictabelts in evidence were copies, not originals, Mack says . Such copies could easily have been altered (accidentally or on purpose) to include the Decker cross talk .
 The channel 2 recording is time compressed, requiring anyone interested in faking cross talk on channel 1 to do much more than play the recording in the background . Of course, this explanation doesn't take into account the fact that the recording is compressed .
 The advertisement lists an “input attenuator’s” present in the recording system . The advertisement shows an ‘in-built’ microphone .
 The report, which picked up where the CBA left off on the issue of AGC, effectively eliminated the argument that the Decker cross talk was dubbed onto the recording after the fact .
 IBM team offered Mack an opportunity to present evidence in support of his claim . Mack failed to respond to the IBM team's request for evidence .
 Garwin wrote, “I told Gary Mack that I would be most interested in a written report or letter from experts at Motorola’s Motorola .”
 I told him also that I would be willing to test such a receiver if they found it for me . "I told him that he would be prepared to test it," he said of the receiver .
 The only means of alteration left for the critics to maintain the cross talk was a forgery is some form of editing . The original Dictabelt sounds might have been copied to magnetic audiotape, altered, then recorded back onto a new Dictaelt to disguise the alteration
 The audiotape can be restored by rejoining the two remaining halves with adhesive tape . Once the objectionable material is excised, it can be excised .
 The resulting taped splice can be ‘hidden’ from anyone physically examining the audiotape by simply making a copy of the recording and presenting the copy as if it were the original . The resulting splice is “hidden” from anyone .
 HSCA acousticians thought the sounds were gunshots . Yet, we know that couldn’t have happened because the Decker cross talk actually overlaps the impulse sounds the acoustician thought were gunshots.
 The only way to achieve this overlapping effect is by taking the channel 1 and 2 recorded transmissions, playing them back simultaneously, and re-recording them onto a third recording medium—a possibility the CBA conclusively ruled out .
 HSCA acoustic teams determined what was thought to be the sound of a “bell” on the channel 1 recording was actually an “electrical disturbance” recorded simultaneously on both channels 1 and 2 .
 This verified the relative speed and timing of the two channels, providing another means of synchronizing the two police channels independent of the Decker cross talk . The impulse sounds thought by the HSCA’s acoustic experts to be gunshots were recorded at least one minute after the assassination .
 Die-hard critics continued to argue the merits of the acoustic evidence in obscure conspiracy publications and Internet newsgroups .
 Author Gerald Posner writes that Dallas sheriff Jim Bowles “discovered the source of the unusual bell tone on the tape’s tape . Several years passed before a new author discovered the source, Posner says .
 The attack on the CBA’s finding came from a heavyweight, an expert on fruit flies . This time the attack came from an expert who is a specialist in fruit fly .
 Study validated HSCA’s original conclusion that four shots were fired at President Kennedy, one of which was fired from the grassy knoll . Study published in the British journal Science & Justice .
 The odds were now only 1 in 100,000 that the CBA was correct in concluding that the impulse sounds, described as being gunshots by the HSCA, were recorded one minute after the assassination .
 Thomas cannot be blithely ignored, despite his background . But in a poor parallel, just as a wise man can say something foolish and a foolish man something wise, Thomas can't be ignored .
 Thomas became interested in the Kennedy assassination after seeing Oliver Stone’s 1991 fictional epic JFK . Thomas believed that the shot from the grassy knoll (number three in the HSCA's sequence) was the one that killed JFK .
 The heart of Thomas' claim that the HSCA’s acoustic evidence was valid was valid, and the CBA was wrong, centers around an instance of cross talk that appears on the channel 1 recording several minutes after the shooting .
 The impulse sounds detected by HSCA acoustic experts correlate exactly with the time of the assassination . When this cross talk is used to synchronize the two channels, it shows, he says, that the impulse sounds are consistent with the assassination.
 He believed that the channel 2 recording represented a nearly continuous recording during the 3-minute interval following the assassination . That is demonstrably false . He said that the recording was nearly continuous .
 The new recording showed that the channel 2 recorder did not run continuously during the 3-minute period after the assassination . Thomas’s subsequent claim that the recorder was not running continuously was incorrect .
 One wonders how all of this escaped Thomas’s attention, since he obviously must have had a copy of the CBA Report . Thomas: “I’m not surprised. I’ll be surprised.”
 Thomas seems to have been given credit by the conspiracy community for the Bellah cross talk ‘discovery” to attack the CBA findings . Gary Mack, who started the whole Dictabelt analysis movement back in 1976, was way ahead of Thomas .
 Thomas, in his article, did not acknowledge Mack’s earlier discovery, but Mack said this was not intentional on Thomas’ part . Mack said it was not deliberate on Thomas' part to acknowledge Mack's discovery .
 Mack satisfied Thomas was ‘unaware’ of his earlier discovery at the time he wrote his article . Mack satisfied that Thomas was "unaware" of his previous discovery . Mack says Thomas was not aware of his discovery .
 Unlike his earlier pronouncement, Thomas’s retraction received no publicity . Thomas retracted his retraction, which garnered considerable national press .
 Even Blakey, who had trumpeted Thomas’s original report as corroborating Barger, Weiss, and Aschkenasy, never heard about it . In fact, his retraction was so unknown that even Blakey had never heard of it .

 The transmission is accompanied by heterodyne tones, a scientific impossibility if the transmission were actually “crosstalk” as Thomas and Bowles believe . What I find most impressive is the fact that the transmissions are accompanied by hongodyne tones . The transmission
 A heterodyne tone is an audible beep-like sound that occurs when a police officer attempts a radio transmission while another police officer is already transmitting over the same frequency . The sound occurs when the officer attempts to transmit over the frequency of a police radio transmission .
 The officer who said what sounds like “Alright, Chaney” opened his microphone, a heterodyne tone was produced . The motorcycle with the open microphone was already transmitting sounds over channel 1 .
 The moment that officer stopped transmitting, the heterodyne tone stopped . The officer's voice was heard in the background of the recording .
 If one listens carefully to the transmission on channel 1 that Thomas and Bowles believe to be Deputy Chief Fisher, you will hear a heterodyne tone accompanying the transmission . The transmission is believed to be a signal from the police .
 This is indicative of two competing open microphones attempting to share the same frequency simultaneously . This is not “crosstalk” as Thomas and Bowles surmise . It's indicative of a competing open microphone sharing the same frequencies .
 If the transmission in question was “crosstalk” (i.e., one open microphone was picking up the sounds of a second radio turned to another channel) there would be no accompanying heterodyne tone because two microphones would not be competing for the same frequency .
 Only one microphone would be open, not two, if the suspect transmission was truly “crosstalk” Thomas and Bowles contend . Only one of the two microphones is open, they say . Thomas, Bowles say .
 If the “Fisher transmission” is not “crosstalk,” and I firmly believe the presence of heterodyne tones proves that it is not, then the ‘Fisher . transmission’ cannot be used to tie channels 1 and 2 together

 Many of the autopsy photographs, when combined in pairs, produce stereoscopic images . The autopsy photographs have not been altered, says the author .
 Stereoscopic images enable us to see a photographic scene in three dimensions, as opposed to the normal two-dimensional view we’re used to seeing in family snapshots . The images can be taken in 3D or 4D and can be viewed in different ways .
 A pair of stereo images (i.e., two separate photographs, taken from two slightly different vantage points) adds depth to our perception . That’s because a stereo image is taken from a different vantage point . A stereo image adds depth in the same way our two eyes,
 The ability to view an image stereoscopically allows the human eye to easily spot the differences between two photographs that make up the stereo pair . According to photographic expert and HSCA panel member Frank Scott, the ability .
 Any attempt to alter either image causes the altered portion of the image to appear to “float” or lie either in front of or behind the plane or “space” in which it should actually be lying .
 A detailed stereoscopic image is impossible to alter without detection, and therefore, any pair of images that can be viewed in this manner, without revealing the obvious signs of forgery, have to be authentic .
 The autopsy photographer who photographed the president’s body took two or more pictures, from approximately the same viewpoint, of each part of the body being photographed . Fortunately, the autopsy photographer was able to take the pictures from the same angle .
 Some of the slight differences in the position of the camera can be combined into stereoscopic pairs . Some of these, because of the difference in the camera's position, can be used to create stereoscopic images .
 Another member of the photographic panel, Calvin McCamy, testified that he agreed with Scott’s conclusions, adding that in his own analysis, he discovered two additional views of the president's body (the back wound and the throat wound) that could be seen stereoscopically .
 Two similar images, produced from the perspective of each eye, are assembled on a disk in such a way that when the disk is inserted into the viewer, the two images are combined into a single scene that exhibits depth .
 McCamy testified that on the issue of alteration of the photographs, he and his colleagues “considered the possibilities of various photographic techniques that could have been used in a train of events to produce these photographs”
 All of the president’s wounds, as depicted in the autopsy photographs, are exactly as they appeared the night of the autopsy . The photographs have not been “doctored,” faked, or altered in any way .
 This fact alone demolishes conspiracy theorists’ allegations that photographic fakery was used to conceal the plot to kill the president . This fact demolishes the . idea that photographic . fakery . was used in the . plot to hide the president's assassination .
 It also destroys another prime conspiracy belief—that eyewitness descriptions of the president’s wounds that were offered by the Parkland Hospital doctors (and later by some eyewitnesses to the autopsy) are proof that the autopsy photographs had been altered .
 If the autopsy photographs are genuine and unaltered, then eyewitness descriptions of the president’s wounds that contradict those photographs are not proof of alteration, as some critics claim, but nothing more than examples of understandable, mistaken recollections, or if not that .

 James Humes testified that even though the X-rays showed thirty or forty tiny dustlike particle fragments, he and his two colleagues (Boswell and Finck) did not see any of them as they explored the brain .
 X-rays tend to magnify these minute fragments, so they were not too surprised they didn’t see them during the autopsy . Humes explained that they were surprised they weren't seen during autopsy .

 It is a seam or line approximately a third of the way back from the front of the skull that goes in a slightly irregular semicircle across the top and side of the head .

 The photographer was standing at the head of the autopsy table, looking down into the cranial cavity, with the president lying on his back .
 All three outwardly beveled defects were portions of the same exit hole . In other words, all three were the same .

 All we’re talking about here is what happened to that one bullet after it entered the president’s head . All we're talking about is whether the bullet hit the president .

 If formalin fluid is more concentrated, then it will remove fluid from the brain and make the brain lighter than it was on removal from the cranium . If the fluid is concentrated, the brain will be lighter than on removal .
 If formalin fluid is less concentrated, then the brain can gain fluid by absorbing water from the formalin and getting slightly heavier . If the brain absorbs water from formalin, the brain gets lighter and heavier .
 Usually the brain is weighed before it is put in formalin . I don't know which was the case here, but usually the brain weighs .
 It is only assumption that President Kennedy’s brain weighed around 1,400 grams before the assassination .
 The average weight of the brain for someone the president’s age is 1,366 grams, and the range is from 1,069 to 1,605 grams . Average weight of brain for the president's age ranges from .

 In other words, it had begun to “yaw or ‘tumble” before striking the governor’s back, causing the elongated entrance wound . The governor's back was struck by the missile, which hit the back of his back .
 The only bone struck by the bullet, before it exited, was a relatively soft rib located near the exit point on the right side of Connally’s chest . The bullet hit the bone as it was about to exit .
 The exit wound to Kennedy’s throat was believed to be around a quarter of an inch in diameter . Just approximately two feet later, the entrance wound to Connally's back was over twice the size of the exit wound .
 The bullet struck sideways in relation to its flight path. literally causing the bullet to strike sideways . The bullet strike was caused by the bullet striking sideways in its path .

 Gregory easily concluded that the wound on the back of the wrist was the entrance wound based on several factors, including the fact that bits of dark Mohair cloth from Connally’s suit coat had been carried into the wound .
 Gregory had also noted the wound to be ‘ragged’ and concluded that the ragged appearance of the wound was characteristic of an entrance wound caused by an irregular-shaped bullet .
 The sharp edges of such a distorted bullet would produce the ragged edges of the entrance wound . It also would explain how bits of cloth from Connally’s suit coat were caught and dragged into the wound .

 Chad R Zimmerman, a Boulder, Colorado, doctor of chiropractic, elaborated on the neuromuscular reaction of Kennedy .
 When the brain is so rapidly disrupted, chemically mediated neuronal synapses occur on a grand scale, producing rapid, but short-duration contractions of skeletal muscle tissue . This is when a brain is disrupted, the muscle muscle tissue contracts rapidly .
 The result is movement in the direction of the contraction of the stronger muscles . This is the result of the movement in which the muscles are contracting .
 In most cases, back and neck extension occur because of a strength predominance of those muscles . Back and neck extensions occur due to strength of the muscles, not strength predominately .
 Quadriceps are more powerful than the hamstrings, so the quadriceps would win the contraction battle . The net result would be knee extension and hip flexion .
 Gluteal muscles are stronger than quads, so the hip joint would extend . However, the gluteal muscle is stronger than the quads . The hip joint in the hip would extend if the muscles were stronger .
 This so-called jet effect was first enunciated in 1969 by William H Hanson in his book The Shooting of John F Kennedy: One Assassin, Three Shots, Three Hits—No Misses . It was most prominently advocated in 1976 by Nobel Prize-winning physicist Luis W Alvarez .

 Zapruder would have reacted to the three gunshots that day would have almost assuredly caused a startled reaction . The three gunshots were a blur on his film, hence the blur .
 Although a gunshot will produce a blur, a blur does not necessarily have to be caused by a gunshot . The absence of a blur is very strong circumstantial evidence of the absence of the gunshot .
 A cough, an unintentional nudge, a gust of wind, movement of Zapruder’s feet could also cause a blur . Any number of other things, such as a cough, wind or movement, also cause blur .
 Zapruder himself testified before the Warren Commission that his images weren’t very clear for the simple reason that his camera movements were magnified by the telephoto lens setting he was using . The Warren Commission found that Zapruders' images were not very clear .
 The emotional reaction of what one sees through the viewfinder could also easily cause a startled reaction . Further, the emotional reaction could also be caused by what one looks through the camera .

 There is no known way to distinguish a blur or jiggle caused by an involuntary reaction from one caused by, for instance, a voluntary pan/search movement . Analysis can never be conclusive on the number or timing of the shots fired in Dealey Plaza .

 He says he alone fired two series of three shots at a short-range target with the primary purpose being to determine the speed with which the rifle could be fired and the secondary purpose was accuracy . He got the rounds off in 4. and 4.2 seconds .
 Frazier said he could have compensated for if he had wanted to by firing low and to the left, but didn’t . Frazier fired six shots high and right of the aiming point . This was because of a defective scope .
 In one three-shot burst, bullets landed within a two-inch circle, indicating accuracy . However, the important thing is that in one burst, the bullets land within two inches of the circle .
 On the four targets, the three bullets landed high and to the right of the aiming point . The three bullets hit within a threeto five-inch circle of the target .
 The accuracy of the accuracy with which one can fire two shots within 1.66 seconds is not clear at all . On the more interesting question, the HSCA Report, upon scrutiny, does not seem clear .
 Another expert hit one of three targets, with the time between two shots being 1.2 seconds . Time between two hits is 1.3 seconds .
 Oswald had more time than 1.66 seconds to fire his first and second shots . The single-bullet theory has been proved by all the evidence, including the fact Oswald had time to fire .

 Oswald’s Carcano “has a right-handed action” - meaning the bolt action is on the right side of the weapon . Also, as with all military rifles, the Carcano has a right hand-activated bolt action .
 A left-hander could certainly learn to fire a right-handed bolt-action rifle with a fair amount of speed . However, it is much more natural and easier for a left-handed person to do so .

 The Carcano and the revolver were designated as protected items by the U.S. attorney general . The United States acquired formal title to the weapons on November 1, 1966 .

 Two stereophotogrammetric studies (which involved viewing pairs of Zapruder frames in a stereoscopic viewer to produce a single three-dimensional image) confirmed Kennedy was seated close to the right inside surface of the car while Connally was seated well within the car .

 The slope over that distance was determined to be 22 degrees below true horizontal . The slope is 22 degrees lower than true horizontal.

 As technology has continued to evolve, computers have been brought to bear on the concepts of the single-bullet theory .
 For instance, investigators used a computer model to illustrate how a bullet might have passed through Kennedy and Connally . Investigators for the 1988 PBS television program Nova used a model to show the impact .
 Their efforts made no attempt to match up their computer model to known photographs of the shooting .
 The American Bar Association hired Failure Analysis Associates to create computer animations of the shooting for a mock trial at its annual convention in San Francisco in 1992 . Failure Analysis assists failure Analysis Associates .
 The FAA computer experts used the Zapruder film to fix the positions of Kennedy and Connally but only in the key frames of the film . The FAA used the film's key frames to fix Kennedy's positions of Connally and Kennedy's .
 Neither the Nova nor the FAA computer studies attempted to create an animated computer model that matched the entire filmed record as captured by Abraham Zapruder’s camera .
 Myers based his three-dimensional computer models on the historic record to ensure accuracy . Myers' computer models are based on historical data .
 A survey map and calibration photographs were used to build a model of Dealey Plaza, Elm Street, and its surrounding structures . A model of Elm Street was also built of a survey map .
 The original blueprint of the modified 1961 Lincoln convertible in which the president was riding designed by the Hess & Eisenhardt Company of Cincinnati, Ohio, served as a guide .
 Clay busts of both President Kennedy and Governor Connally were sculpted from photographs and converted into computer models . The busts were created from photos and models of the two presidents .
 Myers concludes that Kennedy and Connally were struck by the same bullet . The result of Myers’s efforts is a remarkably compelling view of the assassination of President Kennedy .
 The Warren Commission's published sequence of Zapruder’s frames was taken from color slides of the original film and was furnished to the Commission by Life magazine . Life magazine furnished the Commission with the color slides .
 So-called missing frames were included in all copies of the film made before the original at Life magazine was damaged, including the Commission’s own intact copy, which it made from a Secret Service first-generation copy .
 First and later-generation copies could not have quite the clarity of the original frames that were accidentally destroyed at Life.com . However, by definition, these firstand later-genuine copies of the originals could not be as clear .
 In addition to the four missing frames, there are two additional missing frames that Life officials never mentioned . Life magazine eventually accounted for four of the missing frames in 1967 .
 Two other alteration theorists, Mike Pincher and Roy Schaeffer, claim to have found a discrepancy in the blinking pattern of the limousine's frontmounted emergency lights .
 The emergency lights were controlled by an electronic circuit and should have blinked once every 0.41 second (the equivalent of about seven Zapruder frames) They were determined by measuring the blinking pattern in the Robert Hughes film, an amateur film showing the presidential limousine .
 Unlike Zapruder film, no tests were ever performed to determine the frame rate of the camera Hughes was using that day .
 Without the frame rate, it is impossible to calculate the timing of the pattern . The timing of this pattern is dependent on frame rate .
 Hughes film shows that the blinking pattern is not evenly spaced, as Pincher and Schaeffer contend . Second, the Hughes film is not the same as Hughes film . The blinking pattern in the film is shown to be uneven .
 Hughes film shows the left-side light on for seven frames, while the rightside light stays on for ten frames . The Hughes film was released in November 2013 .
 It is nearly impossible to obtain, for comparison purposes, an accurate blinking pattern from the Zapruder film . Third, it is impossible to get an accurate, accurate blinking patterns from the film .
 Unlike the Hughes film, Zapruder film depicts the limousine in bright sunlight and at an ever-increasing angle to the camera, which makes it nearly impossible to tell (especially in the later portions of the film) whether the emergency lights are on or off .
 An examination of the earliest portion of the Zapruder film, when the blinking pattern is more easily discernible, only confirms the pattern observed in the Hughes film . That would mean that no alteration had been performed on the film, as Pincher and Schaeffer claim . Even
 Many of the frames are composites, combinations of two or more images made to appear as one . Other alterationists contend that a great many frames are composite .
 Between frames Z193 and Z194 the camera moves left, which, according to critics, should produce a blur but doesn’t . The camera should have moved left, but it doesn't do so, critics say .
 Between frames Z194 and Z195 the motorcade occupants appear clearly, even though both the background and the foreground are blurry in Z195 . Z195 is Z194 .
 Both frames contain blurred backgrounds and foregrounds, more so in Z195 . Z195 is Z195, with a blurred background and foregrounded backgrounds .
 The reason is because Zapruder pans left in Z193-194, then reverses direction, panning right in Z194198. The reason for the reversal is because of the reverse direction of the camera .
 The Stemmons sign is blurred in Z212 but the masonry wall holes in the background are quite well defined . Z212 is Z212 and Z212 includes the Stemmon sign .
 The unpublished 1974 manuscript by Fred Newcomb and Perry Adams, “Murder from Within,” contains interviews by the authors with witnesses . The majority of the witnesses thought the limousine had stopped, the authors say .
 Witnesses who said that the limousine “slowed” are the ones who are correct in their recollection . As indicated in an earlier endnote, this is the case .
 Another leading alterationist, Harrison Edward Livingstone, agrees with Lifton . Livingstone is quite knowledgeable about the film and goes beyond Lifton in his analysis .

 The conspirators would have to begin by rear-projecting each frame onto the back of an animator’s drawing table and tracing each successive frame of Kennedy onto a piece of paper .
 These drawings would then be transferred to animation cels and painted . Animation cels would be used to create animation animations . These drawings were then transferred to animations cels to be painted .
 Area around the painted wound on each cel would then be painted black . The area around the wound would then paint black instead of white .
 Another set of cels would then be copied, but with the wound painted black and the rest of the cel clear . The wound would be painted black, but the other part of the cels were clear .
