 Black does not expose the film, the surrounding black of film 1 wouldn’t expose the already exposed Zapruder film . If the copying of the cels was done exactly and the job was done properly on a high quality optical printer, the painted wound would fit right into the
 He then goes on to discuss ‘the problem of registration,” keeping each frame in the same relative position . He then discusses ‘registration’ of frames .
 He writes that “it was easy ... to describe the process of rotoscoping and optical printing, but it would have been impossible for anyone to maintain perfect registration of the wound on the head .
 Without perfect registration the wound would move around on the head, as if it weren’t attached . The wound should be registered properly and registered properly .
 The animated wound would have to move back and forth and up and down in perfect synchronization with Kennedy’s head . The wound would also have to shift with changes in depth and angle .
 This is impossible since even a half a grain’s shift would cut the animated wound free of Kennedy's head and make it look like some grotesque free-floating balloon . Even a small grain of grain would make the wound look like a free floating balloon .
 Part of the flap in front actually flops about in reaction to the violence of Kennedy’s head movements .
 A necessary line told by the buffs to sell their snake oil is that the techniques for performing these alterations have been around for years . The technique for these alterations has been used for years, experts say .
 The Great Train Robbery, King Kong and Mary Poppins use cutting-edge traveling mattes to combine animated characters with live-action footage . They cite a scene from a 1903 silent classic in which a locomotive appears to be bearing down on the audience .
 matte lines and film registration errors give away these efforts, both being examples of problems with early special effects .
 Matte lines were the result of a slight mismatch between the matte (which masked out a portion of the image) and the image replacing the “hole’s” left by the matte .
 These matte lines can be seen surrounding the portion of the image that had been altered . The lines appeared as black, and sometimes blue lines .
 Motion picture film film contains sprocket holes that run alongside the edge of the film . Motion picture films contain a sprocket hole in the middle of the screen .
 A gear in the camera uses these holes to grab and advance the film as each frame is exposed . The holes in these holes are used by the camera to capture and advance film .
 The microscopic differences between the size of the sprocket holes and the teeth on the gear that moves the film through the camera cause small slippages in the film as each frame is advanced .
 Two pieces of film that are run through the same camera will not line up, or “register,” exactly the same, frame to frame . This is necessary in any special effects technique utilizing a traveling matte . These differences become apparent when two pieces of camera are locked together .
 The result of these registration errors is that the added or altered portions of the image appear to move around in relation to the rest of the scene . The result is that these images appear to be moving around in the way of others .
 This problem was eventually reduced for large-format films by adding a second set of sprocket holes opposite the existing set and/or increasing the number of sprockets . This helped prevent the film from slipping .
 Small-format films are unable to accommodate additional sprocket holes because of the films’ original size . Small format films cannot be expanded to accommodate more holes in the sprocket hole holes .
 The reality is that even today, it is highly doubtful that any of the most modern technological advances available in film and photography could do what the buffs said was done over four decades ago .
 Not even the conspiracy theorists who hold to the alteration theory agree on a time frame .

 Conspiracy theorists have made such a major issue out of Oswald’s presumed knowledge of the U-2 . It has to be pointed out that the existence of the plane was no secret .
 Anyone who happened to be near any one of the bases from which it operated would have been able to see it land and take off . Anyone with a close-up view of the aircraft would be able to hear it take off from the base .
 At one base at Giebelstadt in West Germany, pilots often noticed a long, black limousine parked at the end of a runway . As far as the Soviets knew about it, pilots had often noticed it, at one base .
 A simple license plate check revealed that the car was registered to an embassy of an Eastern Bloc country . It was registered with the embassy of that country . The car is registered with an embassy in the country .
 For the Soviets, the problem was not finding out that such a plane existed, or even its capabilities . Instead, it was finding out about the plane's capabilities . The plane was a Soviet spy plane that could be capable of carrying a nuclear missile .

 The INS invoked a section of the Immigration and Naturalization Act, which it normally waived, that prohibited the issuance of immigrant visas to those in countries which have unduly delayed accepting the return of persons sought to be deported from the United States . The INS decided to invoke a section .
 On February 28,1962, the San Antonio office approved the petition, but inexplicably in the “Remarks” section of its letter to Oswald in Minsk, which he received on March 15, there is no reference to the nonwaiver . Pursuant to
 The words “Enclosed is your marriage certificate submitted to support the visa petitions” were typed in . Instead of the words ‘Enclosed’ is “your marriage certificate” instead of “enclosed” it was “Your marriage certificate .
 The INS was not going to allow Marina in the country, and the petition itself, which was not sent back to Oswald, presumably contained the non-waiver of sanctions language in it . Nevertheless, the reality is that the INS was .
 On March 27,1962, Michel Cieplinski, the acting administrator in the Department of State, wrote a letter to Raymond F Farrell, the INS commissioner, seeking a reversal .
 If Mrs. Oswald is not issued a visa by the Embassy, the Soviet Government will be in a position to claim that it has done all it can to prevent the separation of the family by issuing her a visa .
 Mrs. Oswald was allowed to leave with her husband and child, but this country was preventing her from leaving, it was said . She was denied the required exit permission by the U.S. government .
 Oswald attempted to have his Marine Corps undesirable discharge set aside June 18, 1962 . Oswald was in the Marine Corps during the Second World War . Oswald had been discharged from the Marines in 1962 .
 His application was to have his undesirable discharge set aside so he could “remain a member of the U.S.M.C.R.”—that is, of course, remain a reserve . What is curious about his brief is a statement near the very end
 He said he would like to include a request for the recommedation for reenlistment regarless of the finding’s of the Board .
 Oswald tried to reenlist for active duty in the Marines, it came out of the blue, in that there is nothing else in the record to indicate he ever wanted to do so . Oswald is a Marine veteran who served in World War II .
 One allegation that Oswald was being watched appeared in The Minority of One in 1964 . Oswald was accused of being being watched by Oswald's family .

 All such work was carried out in a separate department of the company by personnel who had security clearances . Oswald had no access to that department or material used or produced there .
 Dennis Ofstein told the Warren Commission that Oswald had once asked him if he knew anything about microdot printing . Ofstein said Oswald asked him about “microdot” printing . Microdot printing is a means of reducing type or photographs to a very small form .
 Oswald told Oswald told him spies sometime sent messages and pictures under a postage stamp . Oswald said spies often sent messages under the stamp .
 Ofstein told Ofstein he knew nothing about this, and didn't know whether Oswald had read about this or acquired knowledge of it some other way . Ofstein said he didn’t know if Oswald had knowledge of this or how it happened .

Apart from a brief period in New Orleans, when he was getting dirty while working at the coffee company and lost interest in his personal hygiene, the record is consistent .
 Oswald’s political manifesto is printed out on nine pages of lined paper . This document, seemingly Oswald's political manifesto, was printed out in Oswald's home .
 There were also several additional pages on which he tried to sketch out, more in outline form, the principles of a new form of government .
 That the right of free enterprize and collective entryprize be gauranteed . That is the right to free entry prize and collective enter prize .
 B That Fasism be abolished . C That nationilizism be excluded from every-day life. B that Fasism should be abolished. C That is not the case for nationalism .
 E the right of the free, uninhibated action of religious insistutions of any type or denomination to freely function G Univeral Sufferage for all persons over 18 years of age .
 Freedom of desimanation [dissemination of opions through press] through press or declaration or speech . Freedom of speech is freedom of expression .
 I that the desemanation of war propaganda be forbidden as well as the manufactor of weapons of mass destruction be forbidden . I also want to ban the production of weapons that could be used to make mass destruction .
 K nationalization or communinizing of private enterprize be forbidden . Nationalization of private entryprize or collective prize will not be permitted .
 That combining of separate collective or private enterprizes into single collective units be considered as communistic . M. M. combined of separate . or private entries into single . units could be considered communistic.
 N That no taxes be levied against indivuals . O That heavy grauated taxes of from 30% to 90% be leveled against surplus profit gains . N That . heavy grauation taxes of between 30% and 90% should be leveled . against surplus profits .

 The first suspect in the Walker shooting was a drifter named William Duff whom Walker had befriended . Duff called Walker a "batman," an officer’s servant . Duff was the first suspect .
 He allegedly told the daughter of an anonymous lady who called a secretary in Walker’s office that he had been in on the shooting of Walker . He was not living with Walker on April 10, 1963 .

 Surrey followed the men into downtown Dallas . Surrey says the men got in the car and drove off, but Surrey followed them into downtown . Surrey: "When they got into the car, they got in, they drove off"
 Surrey gave up the tail after an odd turn, which suggested they had spotted him and were doubling back . Eventually they made a turn, suggesting they were trying to double back, and Surrey gave it up . Surrey was eventually forced to abandon the chase .
 Walker reported the incident to Walker the next morning, but nothing came of it . Walker reported it to the police, but there was no license number to trace . Walker was not charged .
 Oswald took photos of the back of Walker’s house showing a lightcolored car parked there . Area where the rear license plate would normally be mounted had been torn out of the print .
 The hole in the photograph is not confined to the small license plate area . The hole is not only in the small plate area, but also in the license plate .
 It is a very large hole, encompassing almost one-third of the rear trunk area . The hole is the largest hole in the trunk area of the vehicle .
 It is likely that the hole was accidentally torn out by someone, perhaps even Oswald . The hole in the hole is likely to have been torn out, perhaps by Oswald .
 Marina, who might have been expected to notice a hole in the middle of the photograph, testified that she had not seen any hole in it when Lee showed it to her . Marina testified that Lee showed the photo to her, but she didn't see any hole .
 She testified that the photograph was not there when the FBI showed her the photograph months after the killing of the president . On the other hand, she also testified that it also wasn't there when she was shown the photograph .
 Oswald himself made the hole to prevent identification of the car, presumably because it belonged to a supposed accomplice . The issue can never be resolved, but it has been suggested that Oswald made it himself .
 It makes no sense that a conspirator planning to assassinate General Walker would have parked his car directly behind Walker’s house in broad daylight . Oswald's supposed co-conspirator, Oswald, would have included it in one of his surveillance photographs if he had .

 Conspiracy theorist Jack White noticed that the alleged assassination rifle looked different in many of the photographs taken of it that weekend . White was a former Fort Worth advertising executive and graphic artist with an intense interest in photographic evidence .
 The HSCA photographic panel realized at the outset that many critics, like Jack White, had failed to take into account the effects of perspective when an object is photographed . The panel realized that many Warren Commission critics had not taken into account .
 HSCA photographic expert Cecil Kirk discovered yet another first-generation print just a few days before he testified to the panel . The panel pointed out that when a camera lens projects an image of our three-dimensional world onto a two-dimensional sheet of him negative, the result can make

 Someone laying a ruler on the resulting twodimensional photograph, as Jack White did, is going to get different measurements depending on the angle of the rifle to the camera . The photo was taken by White White in New York City .
 The panel undertook extensive ‘tilt’ studies using photogrammetrical mathematics, which allowed them to compute and compare the true dimensions of ten distinctive features on the Mannlicher-Carcano for any given degree of tilt .
 White was invited to testify before the HSCA in 1978 and detail his work for committee members . White was one of the leading conspiracy proponents of the theory that the backyard photographs were fakes .
 Two other experts had made public statements attesting to the “fakery” of the backyard photos . White: “It is fairly obvious . . that they were made to implicate”
 Pickard, appeared in a Canadian Broadcasting Company segment of The Fifth Estate . Pickard denounced the backyard photos as fakes . He said the photos were fake .
 Marina did the normal thing in taking several photos of her husband holding the Carcano . Marina took several photos with her husband, including a few of her photos of him holding the car .
 White was clearly out of his depth, though he was a hero to his fellow conspiracy theorists . White is a hero for conspiracy theorists, but he's clearly not a hero .
 Calvin S McCamy, chairman of the photographic standards management board of the American National Standards Institute, and Sergeant Cecil W Kirk, head of the Metropolitan Police Department’s photographic services unit, speak out .
 The experts were easily able to determine that the first two prints, the ones found in Mrs. Smith, were found in her home, were prints found in the home . The prints were those of the prints that were found on the victim's body .
 All the other prints, all slightly to substantially larger, were printed manually using an enlarger . The other prints were printed using enlargers .
 HSCA experts were certain that the backyard photographs were taken with Oswald’s Imperial Reflex camera to the exclusion of all other cameras . Marina Oswald testified that she took the photos with Oswald's Imperial Reflex .
 The twenty-member panel compared test photographs taken with the subject Oswald camera against the backyard photographs . They found unique scratches and imperfections, known as frame edge markings, identical to both .
 Frame edge markings were identical to test negatives shot in Oswald’s camera . The frame edge markings are identical to those shot in the test negatives .
 Photographic experts also used the principles of photogrammetry to resolve the question of fakery . Photographers used the principle of photography to solve the problem .
 A vanishing-point analysis of the backyard photographs proved, without question, that the photographs are not composites, as critics claimed . Panel member Calvin McCamy testified that a vanishing point analysis proved without question the photographs were not composite .
 The vanishing point in a photograph is the point at which parallel lines appear to converge . McCamy explained that the vanishing point is a point where parallel lines converge .
 In the case of the backyard photographs, the shadows cast by objects in the scene were used to determine the vanishing point . The vanishing point was determined by the shadows of objects in a scene .
 McCamy applied this technique to the backyard photographs . He discovered that all of the shadow lines did, indeed, intersect at the same vanishing point .
 If any part of the photo had contained a portion of another superimposed photo taken when the sun or other source of light was at a slightly different position, the shadow lines would not have converged at the same point .
 The shadow under Oswald’s nose does not change position even though the head is tilted differently in each photo . One aspect of the photos that has troubled critics is the fact that the shadow under the nose .
 The panel asked the Rochester Institute of Technology to create an exhibit that would make it clear to anyone as to how that can happen . The vanishing-point analysis correctly accounted for that .
 When the head was vertical and facing directly toward the camera, the nose shadow pointed directly downward toward the centerline of the lips . The nose shadow can be seen when the head is vertical or facing directly to the camera .
 When the head was tilted only slightly to the left, the shadow moved quite noticeably, pointing toward the left side of the mouth . The shadow moved very noticeably when the head tilted to the right or left .
 When the head was rotated slightly toward its right, the shadow swung back and once again pointed directly toward the centerline of the lips . However, when the head, while still tilted to the left, was turned slightly toward the right .
 The shadow still pointed directly toward the center of the lips . Without moving the head further, the photographers then moved the camera slightly to the left, just enough to compensate for the earlier rotation .
 A simple demonstration of the effect seen in the backyard photographs is one a high schooler could duplicate out in the yard on a sunny day . It was a very simple demonstration .
 There was nothing whatsoever unusual about the shadow under Oswald’s nose, says historian . Oswald's shadow was not unusual, he says . Oswald was the only person to have seen a shadow under his nose .
 The photographic panel tackled a claim that a faint line visible on one of the photographs (133A) betrayed the point at which Oswald's head had been superimposed onto someone else’s body and chin . The panel also tackled the claim that the faint line on the photograph (133
 The committee’s photographic experts examined the first-generation prints under magnification . While it seems absurd that anyone would join a head to a chin instead of following some natural line in the photograph, they examined the images .
 First, it was apparent that the line was more visible in secondand third-generation prints than in first-gen prints, owing to a buildup in contrast .
 As contrast builds in successive copies, the light areas grow lighter, the dark areas darker . The contrast builds as contrast builds on successive copies .
 The line proved not to be photographic at all . It was much finer and more continuous than the photograph’s grain would have allowed . Second, the line proved to be more continuous .
 It loops down from the ear, crossed the chin, looped down again, and then back up to the ear . It loops around the chin and forms a continuous loop . It looped from ear to chin, crossed chin, and again to ear .
 The panel determined that the “line” was, in fact, the edge of a water spot . It was caused by a fine deposit of minerals left on the negative . The panel ruled that the line was actually a line .
 Other such lines were discernible all over the photo, including on the shirt and on the butt of the rifle .
 What looks like the lower edge of Oswald’s chin is simply where the shadow cast by the sun begins . Oswald's lower edge is simply the shadow of the sun .
 The lower part of the chin, with the cleft, is in such heavy shadow that it is virtually invisible . It is in the shadow of the lower area of the face, which is almost completely invisible .
 Both the negative and the prints were scanned into a computer and digitized, which allowed the images to be seen with artificially enhanced contrast . The images were analyzed with regard to the structure of the grain .
 No significant variations, as would be expected from composite photos, were found .
 Prints of varying density made from the single recovered negative revealed a great deal of detail in the shadows that had been invisible before, including individual leaves of the bushes and their shadows . Even the detail on a newspaper lying on the ground was revealed .
 Severely underexposed prints made by the panel revealed detail in the highlights that had been washed out in normally exposed prints . The panel was created by a panel of experts in the U.S.
 An unexpected dividend of the backyard photographs came with the camera moving slightly from shot to shot . The panel found the camera had been moved slightly between shot and shot .
 The panel determined this fact by comparing the distance between a foreground fence post and background fence pickets, as well as a background door, seen in each photo .
 Marina Oswald testified that the photos had been taken with a handheld camera . This indicated that the three backgrounds were not identical, as some critics have claimed .
 Stereoscopic photos can be viewed as a stereoscopic pair, giving a powerful illusion of three dimensions . Further, and more significant, it allowed any two of the photos to be viewed together .
 Any retouching of either photo would have revealed itself by destroying the illusion of depth in that area of the photograph, says McCamy . This in itself, asserted McCamy, was an insurmountable argument against fakery .
 If the background had merely been rephotographed, as Jack White and other critics charged, the image would look no different under stereo viewing than it did to the naked eye, quite two-dimensional . The background would have been re-photographed .
 In stereo it was possible to see that a bush in the background had very few leaves . In stereo, the perception of depth made it easy to distinguish the real leaves from their own shadows behind them .
 In its final report, the HSCA photographic panel went well beyond what critics had even considered on the issue of fake photos . The panel's final report went beyond what the critics had considered .
 The panel discovered shadows visible in the photographs could be used to determine the sequence in which the photos were taken . For instance, shadows visible from the photographs can be used in the sequence of photos .
 Three linear shadows cast by telephone or power lines lying outside the visible area of the images fell across a post in the background .
 As the sun moves across the sky, the three parallel shadows moved across the knot, clearly indicating that the shots were actually taken in reverse order to their exhibit numbers . Presumably there could have been other photos taken in between (Marina’s testimony doesn’t make clear how
 In the second photo the person held the camera more steadily, but cut Oswald’s feet off at the bottom of the frame . In the other photo, the person holds the camera steady, but the person cuts Oswald's feet off .

 In the Manson murder case, the first officer arriving at the murder scene saw horn-rimmed glasses near two trunks in the living room of actress Sharon Tate, one of the victims . The glasses were found in the home of Sharon Tate .
 The glasses somehow ended up on top of a desk . By the time the police arrived, the glasses had been found, they had fallen out of control . The glasses were later found on a desk in Los Angeles .

 Conspiracy author Noel Twyman lifted the allegation of planted shells to new levels in his 1997 book Bloody Treason . He argued that only two empty shells were found, not three, proving that at least one bullet had been fired from somewhere other than the sniper’s nest .
 Twyman pointed to a Dallas police document published in the Warren Commission volumes which listed a number of items that were turned over to the FBI laboratory on the night of November 22 . He said the document was published in Dallas police documents .
 Twyman acknowledged that he originally intended to ignore the handwritten change since it might be explained by a simple correction of an “honest mistake” but changed his mind when another researcher discovered more “evidence” allegedly supporting his theory .  The evidence had been “buried and suppressed in the National Archives under the guise of national security,” says Twyman . The evidence consisted of two negatives (along with eight prints) showing only two 6.5-millimeter shell casings .
 The negatives and photographs were stuffed into an envelope and signed by FBI special agent J Doyle Williams . They were apparently taken by the bureau as part of the documentation of the evidence that was submitted to them by the Dallas police .
 This is a favorite theme of conspiracy theorists—documents and photographs “buried” in the National Archives or in the Warren Commission’s twenty-six volumes of hearings and exhibits . Twyman also noted that the FBI lab report on the shells, returned to This

 Thompson's suggestion that the dented shell hadn’t been fired in or ejected from Oswald’s rifle ignores an incontrovertible fact, he says . Thompson: The shell was fired in, ejected from the rifle, but it was fired out of the rifle .
 All three cartridge cases were proved to have been fired in Oswald’s rifle to the exclusion of all other rifles in the world . Oswald's rifle was the only one of the world's most .
 Oswald’s Carcano was made by Oswald's rifle, the letter said . The letter said that marks from the magazine follower and chamber on one of the cartridge cases were produced by the rifle . The magazine follower marks on a second cartridge case were also produced by Oswald .
 The impressions on the firing pin are left on the primer, located on the base of the cartridge case, when the pin strikes the primer . The impressions are left in the primer on the gun's firing pin .
 When the trigger is pulled and the firing pin strikes the primer, this ignites the mixture, which in turn ignites a propellant powder in the cartridge . The firing pin hits the primer and the mixture ignites when the gun is pulled .
 The extreme gas pressure of the powder pushes the bullet through the barrel and at the same time pushes the cartridge case rearward against the bolt face . The bolt face impressions on the base of the case are as individual and unique as a fingerprint .
 Only one cartridge case had bolt face markings on it that could definitely connect it to the bolt of Oswald’s Carcano . But seizing on the fact that only one of the other two cartridge cases did not come from Oswald's rifle is a non sequitur .
 Thompson is one of the most substantive and objective minds ever produced by the conspiracy community . He knows that several markings other than those from the bolt face of a rifle can prove that an empty cartridge is connected to a subject rifle .
 Three empty cartridges found on the sixth floor were not fired in Oswald’s Carcano, says Hoover . Hoover's letter only addressed itself specifically to the Commission's request, which was to “determine if had been loaded into and extractedfrom rifle more than once ”
 Hoover’s letter and Frazier's testimony are not conflict between them . Hoover's letter was written by Frazier and Hoover's testimony . Frazier testified against Hoover in a federal court hearing .
 A cartridge fired in a weapon, by definition, has to extract and eject its case from the weapon . And to repeat, a . definition, a cartridge fired . in a . weapon,  has to eject and extract the case from a weapon .
 Three shells found beneath the sixthfloor window were fired in and extracted from Oswald’s Carcano rifle . The totality of evidence (including the fact that the vast majority of witnesses in Dealey Plaza heard three shots being fired) shows that the shells were fired from Oswald's Carcano
 It apparently did not occur to Thompson that the cartridge might have been dented while being ejected from the rifle . Thompson apparently didn't seem to realize that the bullet might have dented .

 Gallagher had gotten the same results as Guinn, but simply hadn’t interpreted them correctly . Gallagher: ‘I’m not going to be surprised by the results,’ he said . Gallagher said the results were the same, but Gallagher had interpreted them incorrectly .

 For years, NAA conclusions matching a crime scene bullet with a bullet independently connected to a defendant have been based on the premise that each batch of bullet lead is unique in the concentration of its trace elements .
 If there was a ‘match’ between the crime scene bullet and the bullet independently connected to the defendant, the bullet must have come from the same source and been manufactured at the same time and place . And, therefore, if there is a “match” between the
 If true, the assumption is that when the defendant purchased the bullet that has been independently connected to him, he most likely also purchased, at the same time, the crime scene bullet . It is believed that the bullet was purchased independently of the defendant .
 Emerging empirical evidence seems to support the premise that the premise may not be true, at least not anymore . Guinn in the Kennedy assassination may not even be true anymore .
 The group says bullets from different sources can share trace elements in nearly identical amounts . The group said, as well as the earlier studies, the study found .

 Dr. John K Lattimer, a urologist with an interest in firearms that dates back to his service as a firearms range officer during World War II, secured a bullet just like the stretcher bullet .
 Doctors “compressed sideways in a special vise until its configuration was as close as possible to that of bullet 399’s bullet 399.” The doctors said they had to make the shape of the bullet in a vise in order to get it to fit .
 This required great force because of the high structural density of these bullets, but it did cause the softer lead from the center of the bullet to be extruded from the open rear of the encompassing jacket,” the author says .
 The sliced-off lead weighed 2. grains, three-tenths of a grain less than the 2.2 grains estimated to be missing from the base of the stretcher bullet . The sliced off lead weighed just 2.5 grains .
 Lattimer was able to slice the extruded lead into forty-one small fragments . Perhaps more importantly, the lead was sliced into small pieces .
 During World War II he served in England, Normandy, and Germany as a medical surgeon dealing with all types of war wounds . He was chief of urology or chief of surgery at several U.S Army general hospitals .

 A bullet fragment and a mutilated slug, which critics have touted as evidence of a second rifle, were subjected to analysis in 1978 . The slug and fragment were found to be fragments of a rifle fragment .
 The fragment had been found in 1967 by a roofer working on top of the Massey Roofing Company building in the 1200 block of Elm Street . It was found eight blocks from Dealey Plaza .
 The roofer gave it to his attorney, Bill Mason, ten years later, in April 1977 . The HSCA gave the roofer's lawyer the document to his son, who gave it back to the HSC a decade later .
 The HSCA firearms panel determined that it was a jacketed, soft-point .30 caliber bullet . The bullet was probably manufactured by Remington-Peters .

 The slug was a “jacketed soft point” bullet, not the “full metal jacket” military-type bullet used in the assassination . But the slug was not a full metal jacket, but a jacketed hollow point .
 The Lester bullet, though the same caliber, was different from the assassination bullets . Therefore, the Lester bullet was different to the assassination bullet . Lester bullet is a different caliber .

 A machine gun does not require a separate squeeze of the trigger for each shot fired . A semiautomatic is partly automatic in that it ejects the cartridge case of a fired shot and self-loads a new cartridge into the chamber . A truly automatic weapon, like a machine gun
 As long as the finger of the firer continues to depress the trigger, the weapon spits out bullets until it is empty . The weapon is capable of firing until the fingers of the trigger are empty .

 Conspiracy theorists have named nearly all of the people they say are accused of murdering President Kennedy . Nearly all of them have been named as JFK's assassins .
 Igor "Turk" Vaganov is a Latvian emigrant with as many aliases as bad checks on his resume . The most prominent being Igor “Turk’s” Tippit, a twenty-year-old .
 A reader of Mein Kampf who railed against ‘Jews and niggers,” Vaganov lived in Philadelphia and worked as a credit manager in a bank .
 On several occasions in 1963 he had requested a transfer to Dallas but was turned down . He had requested several times in 1963 that he wanted to play in Dallas .
 On November 7, 1963, he suddenly left Philadelphia with his eighteen-year-old girlfriend, Anne Dulin, marrying her en route . He arrived in Dallas on November 11 or 12 or 12 .
 The couple took up residence in an apartment in the Oak Cliff area of the city . They took up to live in a suburb of Oak Cliff .
 FBI agents went to Vaganov’s apartment, interrogated him, and apparently became satisfied that the .38 caliber revolver and a rifle he had in his bedroom had not been recently fired .
 When Vaganov provided evidence by way of his wife and the apartment manager that he was at the time of the assassination, they eliminated him as a suspect, presumably writing off the episode as a marital spat . The episode was apparently written off as a marriage spat .
 Anne Vaganov told Berendt that her frantic call to her sister the night before the assassination was due to her fear that her husband was going to harm her or himself . It had nothing to do with the assassination, she said .
 Vaganov said he wanted to be able to visit his first wife, who was living in nearby Garland, Texas . He said he had a sense of obligation to his new wife that prevented him from seeing her again .
 Conspiracy theorists have suggested that Vaganov may have been Tippit's assassin . He owned a .38 caliber revolver and drove a red Thunderbird . Conspiracy theorists say he lived just eleven blocks from the murder scene .
 Tippit murder scene witness Domingo Benavides testified before the Warren Commission that “I think there was another car that was in front of me, a red Ford, I believe. I believe’s another car,” he said .
 "I didn't know the man, but I guess he was about twenty-five or thirty, and he pulled over," she says . "He pulled over. He pulled over, and I didn’t know what he was," she adds .

 Vaganov showed no fear of being identified by witnesses as Tippit's killer . He readily agreed with Berendt to meet face-to-face with two of the witnesses, Helen Markham and Domingo Benavides .

 All three almost assuredly were never even in Dealey Plaza at the time of the assassination .
 All three came forward for the first time years later (Beverly Oliver, Virgil “Ed” Hoffman, the deaf-mute, four years later; and Gordon Arnold, fifteen years later). All three significantly changed their story every time they told it, although the
 The stories of these three witnesses are so far-fetched and contradictory that it is easy to form the opinion that not one of them was even present in Dealey Plaza at the time of the assassination . The stories are so absurd that some of the witnesses are not even present .
 Forensic pathologists who examined Kennedy’s body concluded that Kennedy was shot twice from behind, not from the grassy knoll .
 A sixth segment was added in 1995, and in 2003, on the fortieth anniversary of the assassination, three additional segments were released .

 A Pecos doctor, John Dunn, was a crusader who wanted to get to the truth of Estes’ corrupt business practices . Dunn bought the newspaper with an associate in order to publish the results of his dogged investigation . Dunn wanted to expose Estes' corrupt practices .
 The three resulting articles became a sensation that triggered a federal investigation of Estes and won a Pulitzer Prize for the writer . Estes was investigated by the federal government .
 The grand jury concluded that “Henry H Marshall’s death was a homicide, not a suicide,” went on to say . The parties named as participants in the offense are deceased, and therefore it is not possible for the grand jury to return an indictment .
 You can have only unindicted co-conspirators where there is an indictment . You can only have unindictment co-contradicts where there has been an indictment. You can't have an indictment where there's an indictment, he says .
 Common sense tells us that if there had been any indictment naming LBJ as an unindicted co-conspirator, surely it would have surfaced by now . Moreover, common sense says that if LBJ had been indicted for murder, he would have been found guilty of it .
 Sources requested anonymity since grand jury testimony is secret under Texas state law . The sources requested anonymity .
 Estes testified he attended three meetings with Johnson, two in Washington and one at the Driskill Hotel in Austin . Estes said they discussed the need to stop Marshall Marshall .
 Robertson County district attorney John Paschall would not reveal the identities of those Estes named . Paschall noted that “they’re all dead,” making it all the easier for Estes to make his charges, and impossible to indict .
 Former U.S. district court judge Barefoot Sanders says the FBI investigated the Marshall case "to some extent" The FBI found nothing that tied Johnson, Estes, Carter, or Wallace to Marshall’s death .
 Marshall’s death in 1964 was investigated by the United States Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, chaired by Senator John L McClellan . The subcommittee was unable to substantiate any connection between Marshall's death and Estes' investigation of Estes .

 Johann Rush, the cameraman for WDSU in New Orleans who filmed Oswald distributing Fair Play for Cuba leaflets in front of the International Trade Mart on August 16, 1963, has been a student of the Kennedy assassination for years . Rush has come up with a subtle motive for the assassination

 The motive was his idea to shoot the President... and hope right-wingers would be blamed for the assassination . The motive for the shooting was his own idea, he said .
 Rush believes Oswald knew “old-time Communists” would realize they had no choice but to try to exonerate him, and in the process would blame the Far Right for the assassination . Rush believes that Oswald knew he had a chance to be exonerated of his crime .
 Rush’s theory correctly, I think, presupposes that Oswald was willing to do whatever was necessary to hurt the Far Right . Oswald tried to murder one of their leaders, General Walker, to further the Marxist movement here and abroad .
 Rush’s logic that Oswald felt he could hurt the Far Right by murdering Kennedy is hard to accept . Rush's logic is that Oswald wanted to hurt the far right by killing Kennedy .
 He knew his defection to Russia was well known and did everything possible to publicize his devotion to international Marxism and Castro’s Cuba . He had to know that if he was apprehended, it would be the Communists, not the Far Right, who would immediately be suspected, which
 Even if he was believed to have acted alone, he could only hurt, not help, the cause of Communism . He could only help, not helping, Communism, says historian .
 In so doing he served the Communist cause its worse setback in the forty-six years since its baneful inception,” said the Baltimore News-Post on November 23, 1963 .
 Oswald had no reason to believe the Far Right would be blamed for JFK's assassination . Political climate in Dallas at the time of the president’s visit was a cauldron of right-wing fervor and anti-Kennedy hatred . Only if Oswald felt extremely confident he could escape
 The fact that he left his wedding ring and virtually all his money behind for Marina suggests he was well aware he might not survive his horrendous deed . But he also left virtually all of his wife's wedding ring .
 Majority of Americans have come to believe that one or more agencies of the American government (or organized crime) were behind the assassination . It is highly problematic that Oswald would have contemplated this at the time he killed Kennedy, and did so, as Rush posits .
 He would have little basis for believing that any substantive evidence would ever surface implicating some other person or group in the murder he knew he alone had committed . He would be unlikely to believe that any of his friends or family members would be able to come forward .

 Warren Commission critics and conspiracy theorists have attacked the case against Oswald as being weak because it was “only circumstantial” The implication is that any case based on circumstantials evidence is not solid . A note about evidence: For years, Warren .
 circumstantial evidence has erroneously come to be associated in the lay mind and vernacular with an anemic case, but nothing could be further from the truth . Indeed, circumstantials have erroneously been associated with anemic cases, but that is incorrect .
 Whether a circumstantial case is strong or not depends on what type of evidence one is talking about, says CNN.com's John Sutter .
 If it's physical circumstantial evidence, the case could hardly be stronger . Physical evidence, such as the murder weapon being traced to the defendant by bullet matchups, is stronger . DNA or fingerprints are also present in the Oswald case .
 The true circumstantial evidence case is one in which there is no direct evidence and there are no bullet, blood, hair, semen, or fingerprint matchups . There is no physical evidence of any kind whatsoever, such as clothing or glasses, connecting the defendant to the crime .
 Oswald case bears no resemblance to the case against Oswald . Oswald was charged with murder in the assassination of President Lincoln Lincoln in 1917 .
 Direct evidence is evidence which, if true, proves a fact in issue without the necessity of drawing any inference . With respect to the distinction between circumstantial evidence and direct evidence, direct evidence is . If true, it is evidence that proves fact in question without the need to draw any
 Direct evidence can only be given by the testimony of a witness who purports to have actual knowledge of that fact . Almost by definition, direct evidence cannot be given directly by a witness .
 The most common type of direct evidence in a criminal trial is eyewitness testimony . Witness testimony is the most common form of evidence in criminal trials .
 Circumstantial evidence, on the other hand, is evidence which only tends to prove a fact in issue by proving a secondary fact . Circumstance evidence is based on circumstantial evidence, rather than circumstantry evidence, which tends to tend to prove the facts in issue
 From this secondary fact, an inference can be drawn that the fact in issue exists . From this inference can then be drawn to the fact that the issue in question exists .
 The identity of the thief is the fact in issue . For example, from the secondary fact of seeing a stolen television set in the defendant’s home, one reasonable inference is that it was he who stole the set, the judge says .
 If the defendant’s fingerprints are found at the scene of a burglary, this is circumstantial evidence that it was he who committed the burglary . In another example, if the defendant's fingerprints are . found at . scene of burglary, it could be circumstantially evidence that
 It is not conclusive since he could have left his prints there at some other time . However, it is not inconclusive since the prints could have been left there some other times .
 We can analogize this type of circumstantial evidence to the spelling of a word, such as spelling, to a word .
 With the addition of each letter, the number of possibilities dwindles . But with each letter being added, the possibilities dwindle .
 The witness who testifies to seeing the television set in the defendant’s home is furnishing direct evidence of that specific fact, but only circumstantial evidence that the defendant stole it . The witness could have come into possession of the set in other ways, since he could have
 All evidence, even eyewitness testimony and a defendant’s confession, requires that some inference be drawn . Actually, all evidence, including eyewitness testimony, requires some inference .
 When a witness testifies he saw the defendant rob the victim, from the secondary fact of the witness’s observation, the jury must still draw the inference that the witness was correct . This is not a case of mistaken identity, a not uncommon occurrence .
 The testimony of a police officer that the defendant confessed to a crime still requires the inference that what the defendant said was true, that the confession was not the product of coercion or any other factor . Likewise, the testimony of police officers that a defendant confesses still requires an inference that the
 Arguably, then, it could be said that there is no such thing as direct evidence . It could be argued that there are no such things as direct .
 If the only inference sought is that the fact testified to is true, then the evidence is still deemed to be direct evidence . But if the only inferences sought are that some other facts are true, that's not circumstantial evidence, then it's still considered direct evidence.
 Warren Commission critic Sylvia Meagher says, “Oswald’s visit to Irving on Thursday night, November 21, may not have been unprecedented” (Meagher, Accessories after the Fact,37), but there is no credible evidence to support this . Meagher:

 Tarrants, almost five months after the assassination, would be able to look back and recall whether Oswald cashed the check on Thursday as opposed to Friday night . At that time she would have no reason to make note of what night Oswald was at the store .
 Marina Oswald, Ruth Paine, and Wesley Frazier would have every reason to remember that Oswald had never, before November 21, come to Irving on a Thursday night . Oswald, who had never been to Irving before, had never come to the city on such a date .

 A myth that has taken hold among a great number of people outside the criminal justice system is the supposed unreliability of eyewitness identification . The myth is that eyewitness identification can be unreliable .
 An eyewitness to a crime has always been and will always be a critically important witness at a criminal trial . Witness is highly prized by the prosecution and given great weight by the jury . Witness testimony is often a "star witness for the prosecution" witness, highly prized .
 Pointing a finger at the defendant from the witness stand has sent countless defendants to prison and death row throughout the years . “He’s the man who raped (or robbed, etc.) me” or “the man I saw shoot the victim” has sent
 The basis for the value of eyewitness identification is that there is something incredibly distinctive about a human face . There is something that is very distinctive about the human face, says CNN.com .
 No two people, other than identical twins, look exactly alike . So unique that out of the over six billion people on the face of the globe, no two people are exactly identical .
 So unique that we oftentimes recognize people we only knew very casually ten to twenty years ago, we often recognize them very casually . So unique people are so unique that they often recognize each other very casually, ten to 20 years ago .
 Even newborn infants in a crib, even animals, easily recognize a face . So unique that even newborn infants can identify a face from a crib .
 The fragility of the latter (fleeting glance) has been demonstrated by the erroneous identifications that are so common in staged-crime experiments, like someone running into a room of students, grabbing an object like a briefcase and running out, all within seconds .
 To dismiss positive identification of Oswald under the bromide “eyewitness testimony is unreliable” is unfounded . But when people get a good, meaningful look at someone on a clear day, such as in the Tippit murder, they can identify Oswald . To dismiss their positive
 Reynolds gave a stronger identification of Oswald before the Warren Commission than he did five months earlier to the FBI . Reynolds' first recollection is the one we have to place the most reliance on .

 In September of 1975, seven firearm experts from around the country came to Los Angeles to test-fire Sirhan’s gun and reexamine the evidence .
 All seven testifies they were unable to determine the number of bullets fired at the assassination scene . Under questioning by me, all seven testified they were .
 All testified that they could find no evidence of a second gun, although they could not rule out the possibility of the second gun . However, all testified that no evidence was found of another gun .
 Five who were troubled recommended further scientific tests, which were never conducted . Five of those who recommended further tests were never done .

 The day before the Warren Commission submitted its final report to President Johnson, New Times reviewed Joachim Joesten’s book Oswald: Assassin or Fall Guy? New Times started reviewing even offbeat conspiracy books as far back as September 23, 1964 .
 The second article, “A Philadelphia Lawyer Analyzes the Shots, Trajectories and Wounds,” was in the January 1965 edition of Liberation magazine .
 Salandria’s article on the grassy knoll witness appeared in Minority of One, March of 1965 . Her third article, “A Philadelphia Lawyer Analyzes the President's Back and Neck Wounds,” was published in Liberation the same month .
 Salandria’s first article in Minority of One, “The Impossible Tasks of One Assassination Bullet,” was published in its March 1966 edition . The author's first article was published by the magazine in 1966 .
 Well-organized annual conventions of conspiracy theorists did not start until 1991, when a music promoter’s group out of Austin, Texas, called South by Southwest, sponsored the Assassination Symposium .
 Following release of the Oliver Stone movie JFK, the Third Decade series sponsored two conferences in Chicago, the first in 1992 and the second one in 1993 . The latter was one of the biggest assassination conferences ever .
 Third Decade also sponsored a conference in Providence, Rhode Island, in 1993 .
 The Coalition of Political Assassinations was formed in 1993 on the thirtieth anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy . The Coalition was formed on the anniversary of Kennedy's assassination .
 Fensterwald continued to head the group until his death in 1991, when Jim Lesar took over as president . Lesar has held a position he has held to this day since then .
 In 2004 and 2005, the AARC held two conferences on the assassination in Washington, D.C. The 2005 one was particularly impressive in its lineup of prominent speakers .
 COPA held national conferences in Washington, D.C., from 1994 through 1997 and “regional” conferences in Dallas from 1995 through 1997 . John Judge, one of the founders of COPA and its current executive director, told me that COPA conferences were held in Washington
 Since then it has continued to hold a yearly conference in Dallas but denominates it a regional conference . Attendance comes from all over the country .
 COPA also sporadically holds regional conferences in Memphis and Los Angeles . COPA has a primary focus on the respective assassinations of Martin Luther King and Robert F Kennedy .
 JFK Lancer is the Secret Service code name for JFK . COPA conventions, like COPA’s, continue to be called November in Dallas .
 Most of these conventions draw several hundred diehard conspiracy theorists from around the country for two to three days . The attendance fee of $150 to $250 is a hefty sum .

 Second Oswald conspiracy advocates point out that not only did Oswald himself list his height as being different at different times, but actual photos of Oswald show him to have different heights .
 Measurements on October 24, 1956, and August 9, 1963, were by height charts, and the HSCA pointed out what has been known in law enforcement for years—these measurements are unreliable .
 The HSCA said that “unless the subject photographed is standing with his back against the height chart at a correct distance from a properly positioned camera equipped with an appropriate lens, it is unreasonable to assume that the resulting picture is ever a precisely accurate indicator of both height and head size
 Oswald could be expected to tell people his height at various times based on documents he had seen showing his height as measured by a height chart . Oswald could not be measured by himself, since people don't normally measure themselves .
 A 1971 study of 6,682 army personnel that measured their actual heights versus the heights these individuals reported for themselves showed a typical discrepancy of just over one inch .
 People don't always give the same height when asked at various times in their lives . Apart from any motivation of possible vanity, it is well known that people don’t always give same height as they do .
 Conspiracy theorists argue that Oswald gave different heights at different times are necessarily arguing out of both sides of their mouths . Conspiracy theorists who argue Oswald gave . different heights were necessarily arguing for each other .
 If their position is that the difference in height means one is the real Oswald, the other an impersonator, they can only sound silly arguing that in one of the allegedly most sophisticated and complex impersonations ever, the impersonator gave a height two inches different from the height of the man
 Oswald is usually described as being of average height, and photos of him make him look around five feet eight or five feet nine . Oswald has been described as having an average height of around 5 feet eight .

 The main relevance of a signature on a fingerprint card is to help confirm that the fingerprints on the card belong to the party that law enforcement claims they belong to . The fingerprint signature is used to confirm the identity of the person using the card .

 Transcripts are verbatim transcripts from wiretapped phone conversations at the Cuban consulate and Russian embassy and consulate in Mexico City, from September 27 to October 3, 1963 . Transcripts include phone calls from Cuban consulate, Russian embassy, and Cuban embassy .
 It should be noted that two of these conversations do not pertain to Oswald if for no other reason that the person seeking the visa is speaking in Spanish . Oswald is the subject of two of the conversations .
 Oswald had a Spanish dictionary, and Nelson Delgado, a friend of his in the Marines, says he taught Oswald a little Spanish . Oswald was far more fluent in Russian than Spanish .
 Even if he did speak Spanish, there would be no conceivable reason for him to call the Soviet embassy and speak to the staff in Spanish instead of their native language .
 Oswald asked the person to whom he was speaking at the Soviet embassy to speak to him, Oswald, in Russian . In fact, Oswald asked to speak in Russian, Oswald said . Oswald asked for the person he was talking to to speak Russian .
 In any conversation where a male is calling the Soviet embassy and speaking in Spanish, we can know the man is not Oswald . Therefore, in any conversation . We can know that the man who calls the embassy in Spanish speaks in Spanish .
 One of these conversations (October 3, 1963) is erroneously believed by some to pertain to Oswald . The conversation is nonetheless included here because it is still believed to be of Oswald's .
 Man calling says he needs to get a visa to go to , Man inside tells him to call 15 60 55 and ask for the Consul . Man inside says he can't get visa and asks for help in getting a visa for him .
 Man outside [man talking on phone outside the embassy] asks for the address . Man outside asked if the address was for the embassy .
 Woman outside is Silvia Duran from the Cuban Consulate and explains the same thing to another man inside . Woman outside explains the situation to a man inside the Cuban consulate .
 The latter asks her to leave his telephone and name so they can call him later . She leaves him with his phone and name and asks him to leave them to call him again .
 Silvia then furnishes it to him as well as telephone 11 28 47 and she takes that opportunity to say something personal of her that she changed her address and has not been able to notify them so they could send her the bulletin and that now she give it to them . Silvia

 The more a person is tested, the less he tends to react when lying when lying . Also, recommended practice is to ask only three relevant questions, because the more tests a person has to do, less likely to react .

 In 1940, the Roosevelt administration learned that Axis agents had established a “string of espionage bases from Mexico City southward to the Strait of Magellan . The president issued a directive giving the FBI jurisdiction over the gathering of intelligence in Central and South America .
 The bureau set up a precursor to the CIA in the Special Intelligence Service to coordinate intelligence south of the border . State Department, State Department and other governmental agencies also gathered intelligence from Mexico .
 The FBI set up an SIS school to train agents for assignment in Central and South America . The FBI even set up a comprehensive course in conversational Spanish and Portuguese .
 In undercover operations, one FBI agent went to South America as a soap salesman for an American company . The operation was similar to those conducted later by the CIA .
 One man reported to the FBI that his reports were even more important than those to his clients . Another opened a stockbrokerage business in Argentina, from which his reports to FBI were more important .
 Another went to South America under the guise of being an American reporter . Another tried to get into South America with the help of a reporter .
 At one point in 1944, five SIS informants were being detained by Argentine police and it was feared that they might disclose the identities of SIS agents there . Hoover ordered the agents out of Buenos Aires .
 The National Security Act of 1947, creating the CIA, removed the SIS from jurisdiction over the gathering of foreign intelligence . The SIS was statutorally removed from jurisdiction by the CIA in 1947 .
 7,064 enemy aliens in the U.S. were moved from strategic areas, or deported . 7,000 enemy aliens were moved or deported from the United States .

 Hersh alleged that the CIA had spied on and kept dossiers on American dissidents . Hersh and others alleged that CIA had gone far beyond this and had intercepted personal mail of Americans to and from the Soviet Union .

 One of the most bizarre tales in conspiracy assassination literature, and one that conspiracy theorists have treated very seriously . It touches on the same theme as Mark North’s Act of Treason .
 It deals with the story of one Richard Case Nagell (aka Joseph Kramer, Joe Krane, Robert C Nolan) as set forth in The Man Who Knew Too Much by Dick Russell .
 Nagell, a decorated army captain during the Korean War, alleges that as a double agent assigned by the CIA to penetrate Soviet intelligence, he learned that the Soviets became aware before American authorities did of Oswald and former CIA employees plotting to kill Kennedy .
 He claims that the Soviets believed that suspicion for Kennedy’s death would be focused on them because of the defection of Oswald . He says they ordered him to meet with Oswald in Mexico City and try to persuade him not to do it .

 The CIA has been required to submit any proposed covert action to an informal National Security Council group . Dating back to the early years of the Eisenhower administration, the group is known to very few Americans and answering only to president .
 When I checked in 2000, I learned that the group was still in existence, but once again, under a new name, the Policy Coordination Committee . In 2000, it was under the new name of the Committee, which still exists today .
 The original group consisted of the president’s assistant for national security affairs, the undersecretary of state for political affairs, and the director of the Central Intelligence Agency .
 It was originally expanded to include the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff . It was later expanded into a committee of heads of state and national security .
 Special Group was instituted in 1961 to oversee the CIA’s Operation Mongoose, the U.S. government's plan to overthrow Castro . Special Group members included Attorney General Robert Kennedy and Attorney General Maxwell Taylor .
 In February of 1962 Richard Helms took over Bissell’s job as CIA deputy director for plans . Bissell was the CIA's deputy director of plans .
 He told the Church Committee that when he became Bissell’s successor, the plot activities to kill Castro were presented to him as an ongoing project previously authorized .  Richard Helms’s executive assistant, George McManus, took notes of the meeting . George McMcManus took notes from the meeting, which was held at the White House .

 Throughout 1957 and much of 1958, Castro’s forces had been headquartered in the Sierra Maestra mountains in the southeastern region of Cuba . Castro's forces were headquartered there throughout the years .
 The highly loyal and passionate rebels, less than five hundred in number, conducted very effective thrusts and incursions into Batista-held territory throughout Oriente province .
 In September 1958, the rebel forces swept down from the mountains and began their march toward Havana . Batista’s tanks, artillery, and far greater numbers of men in the Batista army were used against the rebels .
 He had started out as the doctor to the rebels’ wounded, but quickly emerged as its most respected combatant . He had been a doctor to rebels' wounded, before becoming a commander .
 The other column was led by Camilo Cienfuegos, who died after Castro had swept to power when his plane was lost at sea in October 1959 .
 Guevara, almost from the beginning, was the one special star of the revolution . He was beyond reproach and admired unconditionally by his fellow warriors . The revolution was born from humble beginnings to humble beginnings .
 Fidel Castro gave Cienfuegos the honor of being the first to arrive in the Cuban capital, on January 3, 1959, two days after Batista had fled . A CIA psychiatric study of Fidel Castro in 1961 said he was given the honor by Castro of being .
 Castro and Guevara entered Havana by tank to the delirious cheers of thousands of Cubans . Castro and Chevara arrived the following day, but it wasn’t until January 7 that they entered Havana .
 Cienfuegos’s disappearance at sea has remained a mystery throughout the years . There has been speculation, without any substantive evidence, that Castro was behind it . There is no substantive evidence that Castro is behind it.
 Major Huber Matos and First Lieutenant Manuel Artime were killed on October 29, 1959, the day after Cienfuegos’s disappearance at sea .
 Artime organized the Movimiento de Recuperacion Revolucionaria, the “Movement for the Recovery of the Revolution,” or MRR . MRR was the first underground movement against Castro’s new regime .
 If there is any credence to this, it would go in the direction of Cienfuegos, like Matos and Artime, becoming disenchanted with Castro because of the Communistic direction in which Castro’s government was going .
 Castro eschews cult of personality of, say, Mao or Stalin or Saddam Hussein . To this very day, Castro has far more billboards and paintings of Guevara on display in Cuba than he does himself .
 In Cuba’s two main museums commemorating the revolution, in Havana and Santiago de Cuba, Guevara is featured over all other members of the revolution . And in Cuba's main museums, in Cuba, including Castro, are also featured .
 He promoted the establishment of trade for goods between the Soviet Union and Cuba . Trade sustained the Cuban economy for years, until the collapse of Soviet Union in 1991 . Basically, he ran the Cuban economic, since his main interest had always been in the redistribution of wealth .
 Guevara quickly became restless, as governance and bureaucracy were not congenial to the revolutionary blood coursing through him . But he became restless and became restless .
 Guevara hoped to spread Marxism throughout Africa and South America . Cuba was merely a laboratory whose experience could be used to combat exploitation of masses .
 His whereabouts became the subject of international speculation in 1967 . The consensus was that he was somewhere in South America training guerrillas in revolutionary warfare .
 All Castro would tell the inquiring media was that Guevara was pursuing ‘revolutionary tasks” somewhere in the world . Castro would say that he would not reveal whereabouts of the guerrilla .
 Castro read the letter to five thousand Cubans assembled in Havana’s Chaplin Theater on October 3, 1965 . The letter was read by Castro in Havana .

 There he was leading a band of fewer than twenty Cuban, Bolivian, and Peruvian Communist guerrillas to foment a revolution against the government of Air Force General Rene Barrientos Ortuno .
 Barrientos assumed power in November of 1964 after a military coup . He aligned himself with wealthy landowners in exploiting the campesinos and the rural poor .
 The CIA dispatched two agents with a background in guerrilla warfare, Eduardo and Felix I Rodriguez, to Bolivia to work closely with the Bolivian army in the effort to capture Guevara . On August 1,1967, the CIA dispatched the two agents to Bolivia . Eduardo
 He had gone there to study medical care among the poor during the CIA-backed attempt by Guatemalan rebels to overthrow the leftist president . The Guatemalan president Jacobo Arbenz Guzman was overthrown .
 Guevara had tried to organize Arbenz supporters in a “last-ditch resistance” to the successful coup . Gueevara had been trying to organize a ‘last-Ditch Resistance’ to the coup .
 On October 8, 1967, near the small Bolivian mountain village of La Higuera, Guevara was injured by gunfire from Bolivians and captured . On October 9, 1967 .
 His clothing torn and tattered, his hair matted and filthy, and blood oozing from his bandaged right leg, he was executed in a La Higuera schoolhouse on the orders of Barrientos .
 The only known picture taken of Guevara in custody on the day he died showed him standing next to his main CIA pursuer, Rodriguez . Rodriguez was the only known photo taken of him in custody .
 Rodriguez had been fighting to overthrow Castro for years . He was a member of the Bay of Pigs invasion force . Rodriguez had infiltrated Cuba before the invasion .
 Castro’s speech to the enormous throng that night, the transcript of which I have read, was as great a tribute to one human being by another as I have ever seen . Castro would repeat the tribute in print and orally many times through the years .
 Castro described Guevara over and over again as being someone of extraordinary— he must have used this adjective fifteen times if he used it once—courage, ability, vision, vision and intelligence, sensitivity, selflessness, compassion, and moral character, whose life was dedicated to
 In Guevara’s posthumously published ‘Bolivian Diary,” he laments about not being able to read or participate in executions without due process . The most common charge made against Gueevara concerns his authorizing and in some instances participating
 Guevara agonized over the justification of capital punishment . He ultimately accepted what was the “standing guerrilla practice” of executing traitors, informers, and especially cruel enemy officers .
 Guevara approved the execution of a fellow guerrilla, a young man named Echevarria, who began engaging in banditry and pillage in areas taken by the guerrilla forces . But there were other executions, after hesitation, such as that of fellow guerrilla .
 There are conflicting reports over whether Guevara enjoyed organizing the firing squads ordered by Castro of Batista’s main henchmen . One of the main problems was the Soviet Union's delays in economic assistance to Cuba and several broken promises .

 Bolivian's death has made him an international icon . His likeness appears on T-shirts, coffee cups, and even boutique clothing throughout the civilized world .
 Che Guevara is revered in La Higuera, a small village in the Spanish city . The name of his village is whispered to the sky or light a candle to his memory . Locals say if you whisper his name, you will find your lost goat or cow .
 After the Bolivian army executed Guevara, they put his body on top of a concrete washbasin for public display in the laundry room of the Our Lady of Malta hospital .
 Guerrillas buried him and a dozen of his fellow guerrillas in a mass grave near the town’s airstrip . They later buried him along with a dozen others . The guerillas are still at large .
 Argentine-Cuban team of forensic pathologists discovered his remains in 1997 . They returned them to Cuba, where his wife and family lived, for reburial . An Argentine-Cuba team of pathologists found his remains .

 The New Orleans DA’s office searched Shaw's elegant French Quarter carriage house . Shaw had been released on $10,000 bond . Shaw was arrested March 1, 1967 .
 Among a great number of items seized were three pieces of rope, one chain, five whips, two pieces of leather, one black hood and cape, and one black gown .

 One of the biggest frauds in the conspiracy movement espoused the Shaw-Ferrie-Oswald troika being involved with the CIA in the assassination is one Robert D Morrow, an electrical engineer by trade from Baltimore . Morrow was involved with anti-Castro Cuban exile groups in
 From 1960 to 1963 Morrow ran an operation in Baltimore to counterfeit $50 million in phony pesos to dump on the Cuban economy to disrupt it . Morrow says he ran the operation to counterfeit the pesos in Baltimore, Maryland .
 Morrow claims the operation was sponsored by the CIA through his friend, Cuban exile leader Mario Garcia Kohly, who he said was the American leader of the Cuban underground . Morrow says the CIA sponsored the operation through friend, exiled leader, Kohly .
 Morrow and Kohly were arrested by the federal government on counterfeiting charges in 1963 . Morrow served short jail sentences for counterfeiting . Kohly and Morrow were arrested on October 1, 1963, in federal court .
 Morrow claims a CIA executive officer asked him to modify four Mannlicher-Carcano rifles used by several ‘hit squads’ to assassinate Kennedy . Morrow says he was asked to modify the rifles by an executive officer in July 1963 .
 He said he delivered the rifles to David Ferrie in New Orleans and later learned they were for Ferrie's, Clay Shaw’s, and Carlos Marcello . The rifles were used in the assassination, he said .
 Morrow believes Ferrie and his associates set up Lee Harvey Oswald as “the patsy” for the assassination . Morrow believes that Ferrie set up Oswald as the "patsy" for the Oswald assassination .

 DA started using money from a DA ‘Fines and Fees Fund’ to pay assistants to conduct investigations of commercial vice in the Bourbon and Canal St. districts of New Orleans .
 The problem was that the money from the fund was only supposed to be used to “defray expenses” of the DA’s office, not to conduct investigations . The money was supposed to only be used for ‘defray’ expenses, not for investigations .
 Disbursements out of the fund had to be approved by a judge of the State Criminal District Court . Further, disbursements were approved by the judge .
 When Garrison took office, one of the judges refused to approve a disbursement from the fund for furnishings for Garrison’s office . One judge refused to OK a disallowment of the fund to furnishings .
 Garrison obtained approval of another judge by allegedly misrepresenting that the first judge had withdrawn his objection . Garrison obtained the approval of the second judge by misrepresenting his objection, Garrison said . Garrison said the judge went on vacation, Garrison obtained another judge's approval .
 All eight judges of the Criminal District Court adopted a rule on October 5, 1962, that no further disbursements from the fund would be approved without the concurrence of at least five of the eight judges . Because of this, all eight judges agreed to the rule .
 The judges ruled that they would not approve disbursements from the fund to pay for the vice investigations . The judges expressed doubt as to the legality under the state constitution of using money from such a fund for investigation purposes .
 Garrison was prosecuted and convicted by a judge from another parish of “criminal defamation” of the judges . Garrison was fined $1,000, and sentenced to four months in jail . Garrison is currently serving a four-month jail sentence .
 Garrison appealed and the Louisiana State Supreme Court affirmed the conviction . Garrison appealed the conviction and the conviction was upheld . Garrison was sentenced to life in prison without parole .
 In 1964, the United States Supreme Court reversed the conviction, holding that the Louisiana statute (La. Louisiana statute) was unconstitutional . The case was overturned by the Supreme Court in 1964 .

 Unlike Novel, there is little question that Arcacha, though not a CIA agent, worked closely with the CIA in the preparation for the Bay of Pigs invasion . Arcacha headed the Cuban Revolutionary Council in New Orleans and the CIA coordinated the invasion effort .
 Arcacha had been a captain in Batista’s army . He was a military attache under his father, a general, at the Cuban embassy in Paris . Arcacha was a captain and was a general under Batista .
 An educated and highly intelligent man, he was, above all, a Cuban patriot . He wanted to return to his Castro-free homeland, he said . He was an educated, intelligent man who wanted return to Cuba .
 Garrison filed conspiracy-to-commit-burglary charges against Arcacha for the Houma burglary . Garrison sought his extradition from Dallas, where he was then living, in 1967 . Garrison: Arcacha should have been extradited from Dallas .

 The same day of Sciambra’s memo, February 27, he interrogated Russo under sodium pentothal at Mercy Hospital in New Orleans, New Orleans . Russo was the subject of the memo . Russo died February 27 .
 Contrary to what is popularly believed, sodium pentothal does not compel the subject to tell the truth . It is not necessary to tell a lie .
 It decreases inhibitions in the subject, making him more likely to express repressed information . Rather than decreasing inhibitions, it decreases the subject's inhibitions .
 There is substantial disagreement over the merits and reliability of narcoanalysis . Most states disallow the admissibility of sodium pentothal-induced statements unless both the prosecution and the defense agree on it .
 The introduction of sodium pentothal into his system by injection into his right arm caused an adverse physiological response . This is why the statements Russo made were made while under sodium . Russo calmed down and gave his questioner, Sciambra, what he wanted to hear .
 In a transcribed interview with William and Leonard Gurvich on January 29,1971, he said, “My head started spinning round and round . . and I started getting violent and upset,” causing the doctors to physically restrain him . William said: “I started getting
