 Aloysius J Habighorst was the New Orleans police officer who fingerprinted Shaw on the evening of March 1, 1967, in the Bureau of Identification room at the N. Orleans Police Department . Shaw was fingerprinted on the night of his death .
 Habighorst testified outside the presence of the jury on February 19, 1969, that the personal information he typed on the back side of the fingerprint card included Shaw’s alleged alias, Clay Bertrand . He said Shaw then signed the card .
 The DA's position was that by Shaw signing the fingerprint card, he had confessed, in writing, to being Clay Bertrand . The DA’s position is that by signing the card, Shaw had confessed to being Bertrand, the case was solved .
 Habighorst had gotten the name Clay Bertrand from Shaw’s arrest report . But it was clear to the trial judge, Edward J Haggerty, that he was flatout lying .
 Habighorst’s credibility was thoroughly destroyed by several witnesses, including fellow members of the New Orleans Police Department .
 Habighorst had testified that Shaw’s attorney, Edward Wegmann, was present in the booking process . Shaw's attorney was definitely present when Shaw signed the fingerprint card, he testified . Shaw was sentenced to life in prison without parole .
 Captain Louis Curole, who was at the jail that night, supported Wegmann’s testimony . He added that it was a general rule at the New Orleans Police Department that lawyers were not allowed in that room, and he had forbidden him to go there .
 Curole testified that the defendant’s arrest report, including aliases, is always sent to the Bureau of Identification room at the time of the booking process . There would have been no reason or need for Habighorst to ask Shaw if he had an alias . Even worse,
 Shaw testified at the hearing that he never told Habighorst his alias was Clay Bertrand . Shaw testified that he signed his name to the fingerprint card, the card was blank, which New Orleans police officer John Perkins said was normal .
 Sergeant Jonas Butzman, a New Orleans police officer who was assigned to be with Shaw throughout the booking and fingerprinting process, said he was present when Habighorst fingerprinted Shaw and the name Clay Bertrand was never used .
 Haggerty refused to allow Shaw’s fingerprint card, with the name Clay Bertrand typed in as an alias, into evidence . He showed absolutely no favoritism to Shaw at the trial, refusing to let him testify .
 Captain Curole's not allowing Shaw’s lawyer, Wegmann, to be present in the Bureau of Identification room during the alleged question by Habighorst violated his constitutional rights under the United States Supreme Court decisions in Miranda Arizona and Escobedo Illinois .
 Haggerty shot back, “The jury is not hearing it, that is the main thing. That's the jury's main thing," he said . The jury will not hear the evidence, he added .
 Judge Haggerty sustained the defense objection to the admissibility of the fingerprint card and Habighorst’s testimony with respect thereto .

 Conspiracy theorists have alleged that they have seen photographs of Ferrie with Shaw, or Oswald, or the three of them together, or some other combination thereof . None of these photographs or films has ever surfaced .
 I can assure you that if any conspiracy theorist had seen such a photograph or film, he would have seized it at gunpoint and run off with it . It would soon appear in papers throughout the country and on the cover of all subsequent conspiracy books .
 No one, not even conspiracy authors, takes these allegations seriously . The proof is that no reference is made to them in virtually all conspiracy books on the assassination .
 The author is not relying on the allegation in any meaningful way to make his case of a conspiracy in the assassination . Even the occasional book that does, mentions the allegation very briefly, and it’s obvious from the context that the author doesn’t rely on it .

 It has been argued that the so-called Gulf of Tonkin incident in August of 1964 militates against the contention that LBJ did not want to go to war in Vietnam . This argument does not appear to have any merit .
 USS Maddox was fired on by three North Vietnamese torpedo boats in the Gulf of Tonkin in 1964 . None of the torpedoes struck the Maddox, though none struck .
 Aircraft from nearby aircraft carrier Ticonderoga destroyed one of the torpedo boats and damaged the other two . Aircraft from the nearby United States aircraft carrier .
 The Maddox and Ticonderoga were in international waters about 28 nautical miles off the North Vietnam coast conducting covert operations at the time of the attack .
 This attack on the Maddox is not in dispute and North Vietnam never denied the attack . In 1997 General Nguyen Dinh Uoc, the director of the Institute of Military History in Hanoi, said that the assault was instituted by a local North Vietnamese commander .
 The Johnson administration did nothing to retaliate against the actions of the Ticonderoga aircraft .
 No one could possibly claim that the Gulf of Tonkin incident reflected any desire by LBJ to go to war . So far up to this point no one could say that LBJ wanted to go war .
 The “LBJ wanted to go to war” proponents make their argument with a second alleged attack, again by three torpedo boats, on the Maddox in the late morning of August 4, 1964 .
 One has to say ‘alleged’ because such an attack was never confirmed to anyone’s complete satisfaction . Such an attack never happened to anyone in the U.S.
 Freak weather effects and overeager sonarman may have accounted for many reports . Freak weather may have contributed to many reports of missing people .
 Sharp called Air Force Lieutenant General David A Burchinal of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and stated he had no doubt that a second attack on Maddox had, indeed, taken place . Sharp continued to investigate and said he had 'no doubt' that the attack had taken place at 5
 On LBJ’s authorization, at 10:43m., U.S. aircraft from the Ticonderoga and Constellation started flying sixty-four sorties against North Vietnamese patrol boat bases .
 First U.S. bombing of North Vietnam in what was to become the Vietnam War . It was the first United States bombing of N Vietnam .
 It was estimated that twenty-five North Vietnamese patrol boats were damaged or destroyed . 90 percent of the oil complex was destroyed .
 Congress gave President Johnson the authority to go to war in Vietnam if he so chose . In other words, Congress gave him the power to go on the war .
 Historian Robert J Hanyok concluded that during this second incident, NSA officers misinterpreted NorthVietnamese intercepts in an apparently honest mistake that there had been an attack .
 The documents were doctored to provide evidence of an actual attack, he says . He says midlevel NSA officials at the NSA discovered the errors very shortly thereafter but covered them up and doctored documents .
 Hanyok’s report also concluded that neither President Johnson and his advisers nor top NSA and Defense Department officials knew of the deception .
 Congress ultimately signed the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, which authorized war with North Vietnam . If Hanyok is correct, this deception played a part in Congress ultimately signing the resolution . The resolution authorized war against North Vietnam.
 No one disputes the first attack on the Maddox, which alone could have contributed substantially to the resolution . So the deception could not have been more serious, although, as indicated .
 Hanyok says the NSA's intelligence officers “deliberately skewed” the evidence passed on to policy makers in LBJ’s administration to lead them to believe that NorthVietnamese ships had attacked American destroyers on August 4,1964 .
 NSA intercepts of North Vietnamese communications never passed on to policy makers, Hanyok says . 90 percent of NSA's intercepts were not passed on by policy makers . The NSA intercepted North Vietnam communications on August 4 .

 George Kennan is usually thought to be the conceiver of this strategy, one which required no birth since it was inevitable .
 He was part of the small staff that reopened the American embassy in Russia’s capital city in 1933 . He returned to Russia in 1944 as the right-hand man of the American ambassador to Russia, Averill Harriman .
 On February 22,1946, he sent the State Department in Washington, D.C., one of the most celebrated cables in U.S. history .
 If the adversary has sufficient force and makes clear his readiness to use it, he rarely has to do so . Thus, if the adversary is prepared to use such force, it will not be necessary to use .
 In the ensuing years, Kennan’s words, of course, presaged the American posture toward the Kremlin, most notably in the Cuban missile crisis sixteen years later .

 A juror who said he was opposed to the death penalty, but could nevertheless vote for it in some egregious cases, could no longer be disqualified for cause . In other words, the juror no longer must be disqualified from the jury .
 Thousands of death penalty verdicts around the country were reversed and remanded for a new trial on the issue of penalty . Witherspoon's ruling was retroactive, and thousands of death sentences were reversed .

 Their interviews of witnesses and reports became what is known as “CDs,” for Warren Commission documents . They appear in volumes 22 through 26 of the Warren Commission volumes . Their interviews are known as "CDs," and appear in collections 22 and 26 .

 I asked the man I call “Mr CD” Bill Drenas of Lowell, Massachusetts, to furnish me with some additional information about the CDs . He knows more about these documents and their provenance than anyone else .
 Many of these CDs, or portions thereof, are reproduced in the Warren Commission volumes as “CEs,” or Warren Commission exhibits . Many of the CDs are reproduced as ‘CEs’
 It would be easy to say that the Warren Commission only put the most important CDs into its volumes as CEs . But any assassination researcher will tell you that there are a great number of important CDs that for whatever reason never made it into the volumes .
 Volume 22 through 26 of the Warren Commission volumes includes the corresponding CD number from which the CE came from . It should be noted that the “ Contents” section at the beginning of each of . each of the . volumes, wherein all the CEs for that volume are listed,
 For clarity, tightening, and mostly to help expedite finding a CE in the volumes, I do not give the page number of the CE that I am quoting from . Only the page numbers in the Warren Commission volume on which the quoted material appears .
 The first fifteen volumes are almost exclusively the sworn testimony of witnesses . The only other things included in these volumes are sixty-one affidavits and two statements .
 The testimony of witnesses in volumes 6 through 15 was taken for the most part by a Warren Commission assistant counsel . The testimony was taken in offices throughout the country, mostly Dallas, mostly .
 Volumes 16 through 18 contain all the Warren Commission exhibits that arose out of, and are referred to, in the testimony of witnesses in the first five volumes . Volumes 17 and 18 include all the exhibits from the first four volumes .
 These CEs only have a number, for example, CE 460, and give no express indication of the witness from whose testimony the CE arose . The CEs are only given a number and a number of witnesses .
 Any exhibit arising out of the testimony is named after the witness who testified . Commission "deposition exhibits" were marked as exhibits during the witnesses’ testimony and placed in volumes 19 through 21 of the Warren Commission volumes .
 Volumes 22 through 26 of the Warren Commission volumes contain, as indicated, “support documents,” CDs that became CEs . The Warren Report was published in its one-volume Warren Report, published in 1996 .
 In the previous paragraph I said that the three-digit number at the beginning of the document refers to the agency or group that “normally” generated the document with that number .
 A document whose three-digit designation would outwardly indicate that it was generated by an agency or group might have been generated by another agency . But very frequently this is not so—a document whose 3,000-plus digit designation would seem to indicate it was created by that agency or
